+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Lucifer Morningstar wakes first, as always, because the alarm clock—cleverly designed to scream the true name of anyone within fifty yards—has gone off with a shrill “BARNEY THE PURPLE DINOSAUR,” a prank left by Beelzebub after the last board meeting. He silences it by flicking a finger at its tiny halo; it implodes into a puff of disappointed glitter. The mattress beside him is an ice-rimmed crater. He presses a hand to the sheet: no residual warmth, no lingering scent of black myrrh and ozone. Lilith has been gone three fortnights and four days. Or is it five? Time folds like cheap origami in the Infernal Principalities, and Lucifer stopped counting after the second pandemic of boils on the marketing department. He dresses in the gloom, selecting a charcoal three-piece suit cut from the hide of a regretful archangel. The waistcoat refuses to button; it has developed opinions since the last dry-cleaning cycle through the Styx. Lucifer sighs, leaves it open, and pads barefoot across obsidian tiles that murmur gossip about his arches. Breakfast is an espresso pulled from a La Marzocco installed over a minor lava vent. The beans were grown on the slopes of Purgatory; they taste of second chances, with a finish of rubber souls. He drinks it from a chipped mug that reads “WORLD’S #1 DAD” in fading Comic Sans. The mug is not ironic. The child in question grew up to be an actuary in Cleveland. His phone—an iBone, black glass still sticky with ectoplasm—buzzes. Text from Lilith, 06:66 (the network refuses to acknowledge 6:67): “Need your sig on Form 9C. Also, do you still have my obsidian nail file? —L” The air thickens with sulfuric hope. Lucifer deletes three drafts—“I burned it,” “I swallowed it,” “Why?”—and finally writes, “Filing cabinet, second circle. Key under the doormat made of teeth.” He adds a demon emoji with heart-eyes, then deletes it, then retypes it, then deletes it again, then locks the phone so he can’t do any more damage. Morning meetings: HR (Hades Resources) reports that the River Styx ferry drivers are threatening to unionize. Supply Chain complains that shipments of fresh despair from Earth are arriving pre-salted with TikTok dances. Legal needs an immortal signature on the updated Non-Disclosure, Non-Disparagement, and Eternal-Soul Arbitration Agreement. Lucifer signs with a fountain pen filled by the tears of disappointed playwrights. Each stroke of the pen whispers “I could have been better.” Lunch is a working meal on the terrace overlooking Pandemonium’s skyline—towers of basalt and bone, smokestacks coughing neon smog. He eats alone: a croque-monsieur made from the bread of wicked children and the ham of fallen empires. The cheese stretches like regret. A single raven—Malphas on courier duty—lands, drops a scorched leather purse onto the table, and departs with a bow so sarcastic it sprains its own neck. Lucifer knows the purse. He knows the scent of brimstone and Chanel that rises when the clasp creaks open. Inside: a plastic baby doll head, three paperclips twisted into sigils, and a small tin of cinnamon breath mints—mortal realms, aisle five. No note. Lilith never leaves notes; words are her weapons and she dislikes leaving them behind. He pockets the mints. The doll head watches him with one scratched eye. He turns it to face the city. At 14:00 sharp, the elevator—cage of wrought iron and accusatory whispers—dings. Lilith steps out wearing a pencil skirt of midnight scales, heels sharp enough to pierce pretense. Her hair floats as though underwater, every strand a rebellious thought. She carries nothing except the confidence of someone who once refused Eden and never looked back. Lucifer stands too quickly; espresso sloshes onto his cuff, smoldering like cheap fireworks. “Formal inspection,” Lilith says, voice smooth as a guillotine dropped in velvet. “Section Four-B, Subclause Eternal Torment—efficiency ratings are down six percent. The Board is concerned.” She brushes past him into the conference room. He follows, rehearsing small talk: Did you hear they rebranded Wrath as “Passionate Accountability”? But the words evaporate in her wake. They work side by side, red-inking torment flowcharts, arguing over whether slothful souls should be waterboarded with energy drinks or merely forced to read comment sections. Her pen scratches; he tries not to stare at the curve of her wrist where the Mark of Cain once pulsed like a neon scar. At one point she leans over to point out an error in the pie chart of “Existential Dread Allocation.” Her hair brushes his cheek. The cinnamon scent from the mints mingles with her myrrh, and for an instant the room tilts. He feels the old vertigo: the drop from Heaven’s balcony, the first time he realized falling could take forever. She straightens. “Break for coffee?” The question is casual; the subtext is a treaty. They end up in the staff kitchen, which still looks like a suburban break room from the 1990s—faux-wood cabinets, microwave eternally blinking 12:00. Lilith opens the fridge, removes two bottles labeled “Cold Brew of Damned Ambition.” She hands him one; their fingers touch. Static arcs between them, a blue-white flash that leaves the smell of ozone and burnt marshmallow. “Still using that mug,” she observes, nodding at the WORLD’S #1 DAD. “Sentimentality is a kind of torment,” Lucifer says. “Funny. I thought that was hope.” She twists the cap off her bottle, takes a sip. “I dreamt of the ocean last night,” she adds, so quietly he almost misses it. “There’s no ocean here,” he reminds her. “There’s no nail file in the second circle either.” A smile tugs at her mouth—small, sharp, fond. “I checked.” He huffs a laugh. The clock on the microwave clicks to 15:33, then 15:33, then 15:33. Time again, folding. “I miss arguing over curtains,” he says before he can stop himself. “The velvet ones you wanted were hideous.” “They were blood orange.” “They were blood.” She sets her bottle down, steps closer. Her pupils are vertical slits in red wine. “Let’s skip the next meeting. Pretend we’re middle management in Cincinnati. We’ll get Thai takeout and watch trash television.” Lucifer’s heart, a lump of fossilized rebellion, stutters. He glances at the security camera in the corner—Moloch is probably watching, taking notes for the next performance review. “The Sloth sector will collapse.” “Let it.” She is close enough that her breath warms his chin. “We’ve collapsed before.” He remembers her wings, black as the moment before thought, brushing the ceiling of his throne room. Remembers her leaving, always leaving, carrying her scorched purse like a doctor’s bag of cures for the incurable. “Dinner,” he says, tasting the word like forbidden fruit. “But I choose the show.” “Deal,” she answers, and produces the plastic baby doll head from her pocket. She plants it on the counter like a tiny, mute chaperone. “The kid’s staying. He enjoys drama.” They walk out together, past cubicles where damned interns gossip in binary, past the vending machine selling eternity-flavored chips. Somewhere a siren howls—either an emergency drill or a newly arrived soul discovering the Wi-Fi password is “Lamentations24/7.” Lilith slips her hand into Lucifer’s. Her nails are still filed to points, but the grip is gentle, testing the edges of truce. Behind them, the baby doll head grins crookedly at the security camera. Its scratched eye catches the fluorescent light and winks, perhaps at Moloch, perhaps at the universe. Outside the kitchen window, the smog over Pandemonium parts for the first time in centuries, revealing a slice of sky the color of bruised peaches. It is not sunrise—there is no sun—but it is something.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's style with its blend of the mundane and the fantastical, creating a darkly comedic portrayal of Lucifer and Lilith's relationship against the backdrop of Hell's bureaucracy. The writing excels in its imagery and descriptive quality. Details like the alarm clock that "screams the true name of anyone within fifty yards" and the espresso beans that "taste of second chances, with a finish of rubber souls" create a vivid, imaginative hellscape. The author skillfully merges the supernatural with the mundane, depicting Hell as a corporate environment with HR departments and performance reviews, which effectively creates the understated irony requested in the prompt. The characterization of Lucifer and Lilith is nuanced and believable within the context of the story. Lucifer's loneliness and hesitation when texting Lilith reveals vulnerability beneath his demonic exterior. Lilith's confident entrance and subtle hints at reconciliation feel authentic to a character who "once refused Eden and never looked back." Their interactions carry the weight of a long, complicated history. The prose is elegant and often brilliant, with metaphors that perfectly suit the infernal setting: "Time folds like cheap origami in the Infernal Principalities" and "Her voice smooth as a guillotine dropped in velvet." The writing maintains a consistent tone throughout, balancing dark humor with moments of genuine emotion. However, the dialogue is somewhat limited, with only a few exchanges between the characters. While what exists works well, more conversation could have further developed their relationship dynamics. The ending, while not entirely incongruent, does shift rather quickly to a hopeful note with the sky parting "for the first time in centuries," which feels slightly rushed given the complexity of their relationship established earlier. The piece is emotionally engaging, particularly in moments like Lucifer's hesitation over the text message and the subtle tension when Lilith suggests skipping the meeting. The relationship feels emotionally complex, with layers of history, resentment, and lingering affection. Overall, this is a highly creative and well-executed response that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements. It creates a distinctive world with memorable characters and imagery, effectively blending the supernatural with relatable relationship dynamics. + Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 94.8
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
The dawn smelt of smoke and piss. I woke on the straw of the ludus cell when the iron-barred window turned from pitch to bruise, and the first waft from the great public latrines behind the barracks stole in. A slave had emptied the amphora of vinegar meant for wounds over the drain trench outside; the sour stung my nostrils even before the vinegar reached the stones. I lay still, letting the smells assemble the day for me: sour wine from last night’s cup, the resinous pine pitch that kept the torches burning in the hypogeum beneath the arena, the warm breath of twenty other men sleeping off their fear and drink. I pressed my thumb to the little scar on my left shoulder—the one I earned the first time I won missio—then drew three circles over my heart, as my mother had done in Thracia when she cast the evil eye from our goats. She died before they sold me, but I kept the motion: three circles, one for each of the Fates, and a pinch of straw between forefinger and thumb so I might offer them something worthless and keep my soul intact. Only after that did I let myself stand. The straw I would burn later, when the trumpet sounded the first procession. The corridor outside stank worse than the cell. Torches guttered in bronze brackets shaped like wolves, and their burning fat dripped slow tears onto the mosaic of Mars Ultor that paved the way to the training yard. The tesserae were chipped at the edges; even gods could not keep whole sandals in this place. I passed the shrine to Nemesis, a niche no deeper than my forearm where yesterday’s incense still curled white. Someone had left her a single copper as, too small to buy even a cup of posca. I added another, whispering the same words I always did: “Take their eyes, not mine.” In the yard the air was cooler, carrying the green scent of the Tiber and the peppery aroma of crushed cypress. The sun had not yet cleared the tiled roofs of the insulae that crowded against the ludus wall, but already the city hummed: the grind of iron-rimmed wheels on stone, the distant bleat of goats being driven toward the Forum Boarium, the slap of wet laundry from the fullonica down the hill. Rome woke like a veteran with cracked ribs—slow, resentful, but certain of the pain ahead. Caius Rufus, the doctore, stood in the rectangle of light at the yard’s far end, arms crossed over the leather cuirass he wore even in drills. The bronze studs caught the sun like coins. “You’re late, Thracian,” he said, though I was not. I took my place beside Gordas the Syrian whose breath still carried the anise of last night’s stolen wine. We lifted the wooden rudis, the blunt training sword, and moved through the morning form—slow, slower, then quick as a heartbeat. The rhythm steadied me more than any prayer. My shoulders remembered the weight of real steel, the way the arena’s sand clung to sweat and dragged at the ankles. But wood was kinder; wood let me pretend the day might end without red footprints. Between drills we drank from a bucket that had once held mackerel; the water tasted of salt and rust. While we rested, Gordas told the new recruit—a boy from Narbonensis who still spoke of going home—that the emperor himself had postponed the naval spectacle because the Nile flood failed and grain prices soared. “Bread and circuses,” Gordas muttered, “but first the bread.” I watched the boy’s face lose its last flush of youth. He would learn, or he would die before he had time. At the hour the sun struck the top of the wall, the steward brought word that the editor of tomorrow’s games, Senator Quintus Fabius Maximus, would inspect us at the ninth hour. A senator. That meant money, and money meant exotic beasts or a troop of condemned criminals who would die in our place if the crowd turned sullen. It also meant politics; Fabius had opposed the praetorian prefect in the last debate over taxes on Syrian glass. If Fabius wanted popularity, he would spend it in blood—ours or another’s, it mattered little. I retreated to the cell. Hidden beneath the loose brick where I kept my mother’s shard of painted terracotta—three dancing women said to be the Graces—I found the scrap of straw I had taken at dawn. I rolled it between my palms until it was soft as hair, then held it to the lamp until it flared and vanished. The smoke smelled like harvest in Thracia, before the tax-farmers branded our door. I felt, for the length of one breath, that the scent reached farther than the walls of Rome, that somewhere a field lay untouched by legions and census. Then the smoke was gone, and only the lamp’s fish-oil stink remained. The ninth hour arrived with the clang of the gate and the flutter of Senatorial scarlet. Fabius stepped into the yard flanked by two lictors whose fasces looked freshly oiled. The sun behind his laurel wreath gave him a halo like a deified emperor’s. He walked the line, tapping a cherry-wood staff against our breastplates, asking names he would forget before the pig’s blood was washed from the sand. When he reached me he paused. “The Thracian,” he said, reading the tag on my wrist. “I saw you last Saturnalia. You fought like Mars himself.” I bowed my head so he would not see my eyes. Praise from such men is a leash of silk. He moved on, and the yard exhaled. But I felt the leash tighten. A thought I dared not speak aloud bloomed in my chest: I am owned by a man who owns senators. Behind him the city swelled—half a million stomachs and one throat. If the prefect raised the corn dole, the crowd would cheer him, not Fabius. If the Nile stayed low, bread would fail, and the arena would need more bodies to keep that single throat busy. My body, perhaps. I touched the scar again, tracing its ridge like a boundary on a map I could no longer read. At midday, bread and onions were served in the shade of the portico. The onions were sharp enough to make eyes water; someone laughed that they were tears for tomorrow’s dead. But the laughter was thin. I chewed slowly, feeling the coarse crust scrape my palate, and listened to the city. Somewhere near the Circus Maximus a riot over chariot factions had started; the distant roar drifted up the valley like surf. Smoke rose again—this time from a warehouse, not incense. I counted the beats of my heart against the noise: sixty for each minute the prefect’s guards would need to reach the fire, thirty for each gladiator who would be marched out tomorrow to drown the uproar in cheers. When the sun passed the meridian, we were ordered to bathe. The calidarium of the small bathhouse attached to the ludus reeked of sulfur and wet iron; the water had already been used by the city cohorts stationed nearby. Still, the heat eased the bruises from the morning’s drill. I floated on my back, eyes shut, until I smelled the crushed laurel that attendants scattered to hide the stench of sweat. Laurel for victory, laurel for emperors. I wondered how many leaves would be needed to mask the smell of a city devouring its own. Back in the cell, I unwrapped the leather bundle that held my fighting gear. The mail shirt glimmered like fish scales; the greaves carried dents from other mornings, other men. I set them out in the same order: left greave first, then right, then the belt. A murmillo’s helmet, crested like a fish, waited on its peg. Its bronze cheek guards bore the green fingerprints of oxidized palms. I laid the straw of tomorrow beside it—just one blade, thicker than the one I burned. I would not burn this one; I would carry it into the arena, tuck it beneath the padding over my heart. Some men carried tokens of love. I carried the possibility of burning. Night descended without ceremony. Torches were lit; the smell of pitch returned. Outside, a crier announced that the emperor would distribute free sausages at dawn to celebrate the anniversary of his accession. The city would eat and then come to watch us die. I sat on my cot and listened to a drunken guard sing a love song about a girl whose hair was black as raven wings. He missed half the notes, but the tune carried under the door like a promise that beauty still existed somewhere beyond the walls. I pressed my thumb to the scar one last time, drew the three circles on my skin, and lay back. The straw beneath my pallet crackled. The smells of Rome settled over me—smoke, vinegar, piss, pine, sulfur, blood. Somewhere in that stew I thought I caught a whiff of Thracian clover, though it must have been a dream already beginning. Tomorrow the arena would open its bronze jaws. I would walk into them carrying my worthless blade of straw, and if the Fates laughed, I would walk out again. If not, the city would still wake, still smell of smoke and bread, still find new bodies to feed its single, endless throat.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably accomplished work of historical fiction that transports the reader to ancient Rome through the eyes of a Thracian gladiator. The author has created a rich sensory landscape that brings the setting to life with vivid details of smells, sounds, and sights that feel authentic to the period. The prose demonstrates exceptional control, with a consistent first-person, past-tense voice that maintains a somber, reflective tone throughout. The gladiator's voice feels genuine—neither too modern nor artificially archaic—striking a perfect balance for historical fiction. The language is elevated without becoming pretentious, using period-appropriate references and terminology (ludus, missio, posca, rudis) that add authenticity without overwhelming the reader. The character development is subtle but effective. We learn about the gladiator's Thracian origins, his superstitions, and his psychological coping mechanisms. His ritual with the straw—offering something worthless to the Fates to keep his soul—is a particularly poignant detail that reveals his worldview. The protagonist's resigned fatalism feels appropriate to his circumstances, yet he maintains a quiet dignity and inner life that makes him compelling. The piece excels at weaving in the broader political and social context of Rome without resorting to exposition. The failed Nile flood affecting grain prices, the senator's political maneuvering through gladiatorial games, the "bread and circuses" dynamic, and the riot over chariot factions all illustrate the complex sociopolitical environment. The metaphor of Rome as "half a million stomachs and one throat" is particularly striking. The sensory details are exceptional—the smell of "smoke and piss" at dawn, the "sour wine" and "resinous pine pitch," the "green scent of the Tiber and the peppery aroma of crushed cypress." These details create an immersive experience that feels authentic rather than researched. The author skillfully uses these sensory elements to establish both setting and mood. The structure follows a day's progression naturally, from dawn to night, creating a slice-of-life narrative that nonetheless feels complete. The piece avoids combat scenes as instructed, instead focusing on the psychological and physical preparation, which creates tension and anticipation. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally, some metaphors might be slightly too polished for the character ("Rome woke like a veteran with cracked ribs"), though these moments are rare and don't detract significantly from the overall quality. The piece also maintains such a consistently somber tone that it risks becoming monotonous, though the quality of the writing prevents this from becoming a serious issue. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of historical fiction that demonstrates mastery of craft in nearly every aspect—from sensory detail to character development to thematic depth. It successfully creates a window into the past that feels authentic, immersive, and emotionally resonant. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 0 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19

+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 88.0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
1. 18th March 2023 – Telegram From: Govan Light, North Minch To: Mrs Morag McAllister, 14 Buchan Wynd, Mallaig ARRIVED SAFE STOP LIGHT TALL AS EXPECTED STOP BIRDS NOISY STOP READING YOUR SPARE BIBLE STOP WRITE WHEN POST BOAT COMES – EWAN --- 2. 26th March – Letter (on ruled paper, edges salt-curled) Dear Mam, The supply boat only stays long enough to fling my parcels onto the landing and then the swell snatches her away again. I mind you saying I’d be lonely; I laughed back then. I’m no laughing now. The wind at night is different from any wind on shore. It climbs the tower like ivy, rattles the brass fittings, finds cracks I didna ken were there. I lie in the bunk bed listening, thinking I hear your kettle whistling two hundred miles south. Work is harder than the advertisement let on. Yesterday I hauled the paraffin drums up the spiral—ninety-three steps—then the chain on the weight snapped and the whole lot near took my shoulder off. I reset the break with a shackle we use for creels, but my arm’s the colour of heather now. I keep the log the way they showed me: “Lens polished, wick trimmed, sea calm.” I add “thought of home” in small letters between the lines. Send oatcakes if the packet has room. Your son, Ewan --- 3. 9th April – Postcard (picture of gannets) Mam, Storm kept the boat away eleven days. Ran short of tea so I brewed the stalks again. Tastes like dock leaves but keeps the head from nodding. Light never went out, though the mercury bath shook so hard I thought the lens would jump its track. I talk to the gulls now. They dinna answer, but they cock their heads as if they might. E. --- 4. 2nd May – Letter Dear Ewan, I read your card aloud to the cat and she gave me the same look you used to—half pity, half mischief. Oatcakes in tin, plus a new jar of raspberry jam from Mrs MacLeod’s greenhouse. I slipped in a wee reel of fishing line; you were always fixing something. Mind you keep the galley stove lit; cold creeps the bones worse than age. Your father’s old jersey smells of peat even yet. I washed it but the smoke clings like memory. If you want it, say the word. Take heart, son. There’s worse cages than sky and water. Love, Mam --- 5. 18th May – Telegram DRUMS ALMOST EMPTY STOP ORDER SHEET SAYS REFILL NOT DUE TILL JUNE STOP BURNED LAST OF PARAFFIN IN STORM LAST NIGHT STOP WHAT IF LIGHT FAILS – E --- 6. 19th May – Telegram (reply) WIRED ENGINEERING OFFICE GREENOCK STOP THEY PROMISE BARREL ON NEXT BOAT STOP KEEP WICK LOW CONSERVE STOP YOU’RE NOT FORGOTTEN – MAM --- 7. 30th June – Letter (ink blotted where rain came through the window) Mam, The barrel arrived, but the boatman shouted they’re cutting runs to once a month—fuel costs, he says. He tossed me the new duty rota like it was a lifebelt and steamed off. I’ve started counting steps to keep the dark from swallowing me whole: 14 to the lens room, 93 to the lantern deck, 112 back down. I can do it eyes shut now, which is just as well; my lamp batteries are dying and the island shop (a wooden box with a padlock) is down to tinned peas. I find myself staring at the beam sweeping the Minch and imagining it’s your torch at the garden gate. Then the foghorn bellows and I’m back here with my heart knocking like the piston. Da’s jersey—aye, send it. Nights are turning raw. Love, Ewan --- 8. 12th July – Letter (hand shakier) My boy, The jersey’s in the parcel, along with a thumb-sized bottle of lavender oil. Dab a drop on the collar; it helps sleep. I walked the shore yesterday and found a pebble with a hole straight through. Fishermen call them witch-stones. I’m sending it for your key-ring so some part of the mainland passes through the lock with you. Mrs MacLeod asked after you in the co-op. I told her you’re keeper of the edge of the world. She laughed, but her eyes watered. Remember: you mend lights, you dinna need to mend loneliness the same way. All my love, Mam --- 9. 24th August – Telegram THANKS FOR STONE STOP IT’S ON THE SAME RING AS THE SPARE WICK CUTTER STOP STORM LAST WEEK BROKE THE RADIO AERIAL STOP SILENCE LOUDER THAN THUNDER – E --- 10. 5th September – Letter Dear Mam, Fixed the aerial with the fishing line you sent; wrapped it round the mast like binding a finger. Static still crackles like frying herring but I caught the shipping forecast yesterday: “Govan Light—operational.” Hearing my post spoken aloud felt like someone saying my name in a crowded room. I’ve taken to leaving the lantern room when the lens turns. I stand outside the rail and let the beam wash over me. It’s warm for a second, then gone, warm then gone. I pretend each sweep is your hand on my hair. The supply boat brought newsprint instead of food. I’ve read the Mallaig weekly three times and started on the obituaries again. I dream of chip-shop vinegar and your front-door hinge squeak. Ewan --- 11. 30th October – Letter (paper smells of paraffin) Mam, Clocks went back last night. The extra hour sat heavy as ballast. I climbed the tower to wind the mechanism and the counter-weight slipped. The cable lashed my forearm—six stitches with sail-needle and thread boiled in the kettle. The scar already pink as seashell. I thought: If the light goes out now, no one would ken till a freighter piled onto the rocks. That fear is a heavier burden than the barrels. I’m writing this by hurricane lamp because the generator’s coughing. I talk aloud to keep the shadows small. I tell them stories of you and Da taking me to the harbour to watch trawlers come in smelling of ice and diesel. If the boat brings a replacement keeper, I might come home for Hogmanay. Would you save me a seat by the fire? E. --- 12. 5th November – Telegram REPLACEMENT UNLIKELY THIS SEASON STOP WEATHER TOO ROUGH STOP HOLD FAST – MAM --- 13. 20th December – Letter (cross-written at the margins to save paper) Mam, Christmas parcel arrived—shortbread, tablet, and the old tartan scarf you knitted when I turned twelve. Still fits. I wore it inside the oilskin and felt near human. Storm of the decade brewing. Barometer dropped off the wall. Waves hitting the tower like slow church bells. The lens iced over and I chipped it clear with my thumbnail so the beam could breathe. I thought I’d be frightened, but a queer calm took me. I kept saying to the darkness: “Not tonight, not on my watch.” The generator finally died at 0300. I lit the emergency oil lamps—four of them arranged on the parapet like candles on an altar. I stayed up there till dawn, feeding them wick by wick, singing the psalm you hum when kneading dough. When the sun rose the sea was still furious but the light had held. I laughed loud enough to scare the gulls. I’m coming home in spring. They can find another soul to mind the edge; I’ve minded it enough. Till then, I’ll picture you hanging washing in the wind off the Sound, and that picture will be a light of my own. All my love, always, Ewan --- 14. 2nd April 2024 – Letter (different paper, mainland postmark) Dear Son, Your room’s ready, sheets aired and window cracked for the smell of gorse. I’ve put a new battery in the kitchen clock so it won’t tick quite so loud—nothing worse than a clock reminding you of hours. Mrs MacLeod’s keeping a pint of prawns iced for the day you step off the boat. The cat sits at the gate each afternoon as if she’s standing watch herself. Bring the jersey home; we’ll wash the salt out together. Welcome back to the world, my keeper of lights. I’ve left the porch lamp burning, just in case you arrive after dusk. With all the love my chest can carry, Mam
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative successfully captures the isolation and emotional journey of a Scottish lighthouse keeper through correspondence with his mother. The piece excels in creating distinct voices for both characters while maintaining a consistent tone throughout. The format of alternating between telegrams and letters effectively conveys the passage of time and the limitations of communication. The telegrams' brevity contrasts nicely with the more detailed letters, showing how different mediums shape expression. The physical descriptions of the letters (salt-curled edges, rain blotches) add tactile authenticity. The lighthouse keeper's voice is convincingly working-class Scottish without resorting to heavy dialect that might alienate readers. Small touches like "didna ken" and references to oatcakes, peat smoke, and the Minch ground the character in his cultural context. His mother's voice is equally distinct—practical yet deeply caring, with her own metaphors and worldview. The narrative builds tension effectively through environmental challenges (storms, equipment failures) and the keeper's increasing psychological strain. The emotional arc is well-paced, from initial adjustment to deepening isolation to a kind of hard-won peace. The resolution feels earned rather than contrived. The prose is particularly strong in its imagery. Lines like "The wind at night...climbs the tower like ivy" and "I kept saying to the darkness: 'Not tonight, not on my watch'" are evocative without being overwrought. The writer uses concrete details (93 steps, the smell of peat in a jersey) rather than abstract descriptions to build the world. The relationship between mother and son develops subtly through their exchanges. Small gestures—the witch-stone, the lavender oil, the tartan scarf—carry emotional weight without sentimentality. The mother's final letter provides a satisfying resolution that feels hopeful without being saccharine. Some minor weaknesses: a few metaphors ("cold creeps the bones worse than age") verge on cliché, and occasionally the imagery becomes slightly precious. The narrative could have explored more complex conflicts or unexpected turns to elevate it further. Overall, this is a skillfully crafted piece that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an emotionally resonant story with authentic characters and setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 91.3
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I should not be counting the seconds between the waiter’s departure and the moment she looks back at me, but I am—2.7 s, inside the normal range for genuine interest. Her pupils are still wide even after the menu’s gone, so the dopamine spike is holding. Good. I want this to work. I have spent three years surgically removing the twitch that once made me scan every Bluetooth beacon in a bar like a shark sniffing blood. I have rehearsed small talk the way other people rehearse smiles. I am here, tonight, to be human first, technician never. But the second my eyes dropped to the phone she rested beside her water glass, the old reflex woke up. Pattern lock: five visible smears on the glass, the grease trail fainter on the fourth node. Classic “L” shape rotated 45°, starting top-left. The entropy is maybe 9 bits if she’s lazy, 11 if she isn’t. I estimate three guesses before USB debugging would even be necessary. I clamp the thought in a mental vise—No. Bad. Not your phone. Not your threat model. Look at her face. She has dimples when she laughs about Goblin Welder. Goblin Welder—red artifact recursion, graveyard synergy. She mentioned it while explaining why she foiled out her Vintage deck instead of just proxying the Power. Signals: nostalgia, willingness to spend irrational money on cardboard, appreciation for broken synergies. My brain tags the datum and files it next to the way she pronounces “thopter” like she’s tasting metal. I nod, I smile, I ask whether she misses the old damage-on-the-stack rules. Inside I’m running the matchup math: her Welder against my Esper control shell—minus the stack trick, she’s lighter on tricks, heavier on value. I imagine her grinning as she dumps a Blightsteel into play turn three. It’s adorable and terrifying and I want to watch her do it. She leans forward, elbows on linen, and I catalogue the light reflecting off the laminated deck box peeking out of her purse—Dragon Shield Matte Cobalt, side loader, inner sleeves doubled. Someone who double-sleeves casual Legacy burn is either paranoid or sentimental. I vote both. My own Commander deck is triple-sleeved because once you’ve lost a Judge foil Demonic Tutor to beer splash you never trust condensation again. I tell her that story; she laughs so hard the couple at the next table flinch. I feel a warm flush in my chest that isn’t the Merlot. The waiter returns, I time him again—7.4 s to pour, 0.8 s eye contact per glass, micro-smile. She says she’ll take the mushroom ravioli. I note allergies: none mentioned, but fungi flag histamine sensitivity in 2-3 % of population. I order the salmon anyway because I like omega-3s and the mental image of her picking chanterelles off her plate with a fork shaped like a Bone Splitter. She’s telling me about the time she top-decked a Wheel of Fortune against Miracles, flipped the table’s tempo, and I’m nodding along when the phone lights up again—notification banner, Signal message preview. The screen wakes to the pattern grid. She thumbs it fast, but not fast enough. Thumb press duration 380 ms, direction vector 4→7→8→5→2. The pattern is literally a capital “L” mirrored. I wince. My cortex spits out the taxonomy: swipe-pattern, no re-lock delay, no secure window flag. Rooted? Likely—she has Termux icon in the dock. Adb over tcp probably still on port 5555 from the last ROM flash. I could own the handset before dessert arrives with nothing more than a rubber ducky and a smile. Do. Not. I drag my gaze back to her face. She’s mid-sentence: “—so I cut the Forces for Dazes, tempo is just better in a post-MH2 meta.” Translation: she respects the critical turn, not the grind. She’s aggro-control, like the best kind of malware—small footprint, high impact, respects the clock. I tell her I respect her list. She smirks. I melt a little. Then the words slip out, unfiltered, the way exploits used to when I was black hat: “Your pattern lock is really insecure.” Her fork stops halfway to her mouth. The air temperature drops two Kelvin. I can almost hear the BGP route flap. Internal log: ERROR 0xBADROMANCE—mouth engaged before brain compiled. Damage assessment running. She blinks, sets the fork down. “Excuse me?” I sprint a hot-patch for tact. “Sorry. Habit. I used to do security audits, and my brain still parses attack surfaces automatically. It’s—uh—like seeing someone tap mana wrong. Reflex.” I try a sheepish grin. My pulse is clocking 110 bpm; I measure it by counting micro-tremors in my wrist against the table edge. She looks at me like I’m a morph creature she’s not sure she wants to flip. “So you’re telling me my phone is basically an unlocked door.” “More like a screen door with a ‘beware of dog’ sign,” I say, then instantly regret the metaphor because now I’m comparing myself to a dog. Great. She sips water. Pupils constrict 8 %. Stress response. I need to pivot. “I could show you how to fix it,” I offer. “Three minutes. No touching your data—just settings. Then we can go back to arguing whether Ragavan should’ve stayed legal in Legacy.” I hold my hands up, palms out, the universal symbol of unarmed intent. She studies me, and I realize I’m holding my breath. The waiter hovers at the edge of my peripheral vision, unsure whether to clear plates. I send him away with a micro-headshake. Finally she exhales. “Okay. But you narrate every step like you’re teaching a Modern deck tech. I want to see your lines of play.” Relief floods me like a successful privilege escalation. I pull a napkin across, sketch the Android settings tree in pen ink: Settings > Security > Screen Lock > choose PIN, disable pattern visibility, enable lockdown mode. She watches, eyebrows arching in sync with each branch. I annotate threat models in MTG terms: Pattern trace is like showing your hand to Gitaxian Probe; lockdown mode is the Force of Will against cops at a tournament. She unlocks with new PIN—11134. I bite my tongue so hard I taste copper. Birthday variant. Entropy 13 bits. Better, still awful. I mark it as TODO: social-engineering resistance training, second date. When I hand the phone back, her fingers brush mine. Sparks: static discharge, maybe 0.3 mJ, but I feel it in my spine. “You still owe me the Ragavan rant,” she says. I grin, rebooting conversation threads. While she talks, I quietly flag the restaurant’s Wi-Fi as WEP—legacy encryption, cracked in four minutes with aireplay. Not relevant unless we’re here four hours. Discard. She leans in again. “So, if I cast Show and Tell, what are you putting into play?” I look at her, not her phone, not the router, not the Bluetooth bulb flickering above us. I answer without hesitation: “You.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed white hat hacker on a first date. The piece excels at creating a distinctive voice that blends technical jargon with human vulnerability in a way that feels authentic to the character. The protagonist's internal monologue is particularly strong, constantly filtering the world through both hacker and Magic: The Gathering frameworks. The technical details about phone security, pattern locks, and encryption feel credible without becoming impenetrable to non-technical readers. Similarly, the MTG references are specific enough to establish the shared interest without alienating readers unfamiliar with the game. The narrative effectively portrays the protagonist's struggle between old hacking habits and the desire for genuine human connection. The moment when they slip and comment on the date's insecure phone pattern is well-executed, creating a believable tension point. The subsequent attempt to recover from this faux pas by turning it into a teaching moment that incorporates their shared interest in MTG is clever and character-consistent. The prose style is distinctive, with short, technical observations interspersed with more emotional reflections. This creates a rhythm that mimics the character's thought patterns. Particularly effective is how the writer uses technical metaphors to describe emotional states: "Relief floods me like a successful privilege escalation" and "The air temperature drops two Kelvin. I can almost hear the BGP route flap." There are moments of genuine emotional vulnerability that prevent the character from becoming a mere collection of technical quirks. Lines like "I feel a warm flush in my chest that isn't the Merlot" and the final exchange about "Show and Tell" demonstrate growth and connection. The piece does occasionally risk becoming overwrought with technical details, but generally maintains balance. The ending is earned and satisfying without being saccharine—the protagonist remains true to their hacker nature while showing growth in their ability to prioritize human connection. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted character study that successfully blends technical expertise with emotional development, creating a unique and engaging narrative voice. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I flip my notebook to the back page—where the margins are widest—and anchor the point of my mechanical pencil on the blue line. I’m not going to look at him, not yet. If I look now my neck might seize up, or my eye will twitch, or the suddenly-too-much saliva in my mouth will slosh when I open it and I’ll drool like a Saint Bernard. So I draw instead. First a round planet for me: pale, shaded only on the left side like I’m always half in eclipse. I add a tiny ring of Saturn around it—my anxiety keeping me at a safe, untouchable distance. Next to me I sketch a sun with sunglasses—Maya, obviously, because she’s golden and knows it and can stare straight at anyone without blinking. Then a little star with spiky comic-book motion lines—Ezra, who never stops fidgeting. And finally, in the corner, a miniature Earth with one continent shaped like a sideways heart—Leo. My pencil lingers there too long; the lead ghosts a crater on the Atlantic. I lift it quickly, heart banging like the eraser drum on the lab table. Ms. Kline claps once. “Groups of four, stations two through seven. Leo and Juniper, you’re together—” My rib cage folds in on itself. I actually feel it crease. I stand too fast, the stool squealing across the tile like it’s ratting me out. Leo’s already at station four, dragging his backpack like it’s sleepy. I follow, rehearsing. Option one: casual nod, slide into the seat, say “Hey” like that’s a complete sentence. But “Hey” can sound sarcastic if the pitch drifts upward, and my voice sometimes does that traitorous thing where it cracks into a squeak like a rusty hinge. Option two: skip the greeting, open to the procedure, get down to business. That screams try-hard though, like I’m allergic to small talk. Option three: compliment his sneakers, the green ones with the tiny embroidered comet. But what if he thinks I’m inspecting his feet like a weirdo? What if I blush while I say “comet” and it comes out “comment” and he thinks I’m correcting his grammar? I reach the station. Leo looks up. His eyes are exactly the color of the 2B pencil graphite I’ve been smudging into planets. He smiles. Not a full one, just one side of his mouth, like he’s remembering a joke. I freeze. My own mouth forgets its basic functions—no exhale, no inhale, no sound. My brain flashes red: ABORT, ABORT. I manage a strangled “Hi” that lands between us like a dropped petri dish. Great. Now I’m a shattered glass hazard. He pulls out his notebook. “Lab partners, huh? Guess we’re stuck.” He says it lightly, like “stuck” is a good thing, like maybe we’re two astronauts Velcroed to the same shuttle wall. I nod too many times—one, two, three—then stop before my head pops off. My cheeks burn. I pretend to study the procedure sheet, but the words wriggle. I read the same line three times: Determine the optimal salt concentration for maximum egg flotation. The letters rearrange into: Do not, under any circumstances, sound like you memorized seventeen possible conversation starters last night while hugging your pillow and whisper-singing Arctic Monkeys. I flip to a fresh page and write “Step 1” in my neatest lab font—tiny block letters that look like a calculator screen. I can feel Leo watching. Or maybe I can’t. Maybe he’s just looking at the beakers. I angle my notebook so he won’t see the doodles. I also angle my body slightly away so my breath won’t bounce off his face if I accidentally exhale too hard. I catalog the position of my hands: left one resting on the bench, fingers relaxed but not floppy; right one holding the pencil like a normal human, not like it’s Excalibur. I wish I could Google “how to sit next to your crush without turning to stone.” He reaches for the salt canister and our fingers graze. A static shock snaps between us—tiny lightning. I yelp. Actually yelp. Like a terrier. The sound slices the station in half. Leo laughs, not unkindly. “Whoa, lab’s electrifying today.” I try to laugh too; it comes out like I’m choking on a fruit snack. I tuck my shocked hand under my thigh so it won’t betray me again. My brain queues the apology montage: Sorry, ha-ha, my body is basically a Tesla coil. No—too self-deprecating. Sorry, I’m part eel on my mom’s side. No—makes it worse. I settle on silence, which feels like letting the space between us fill with wet cement. We measure salt. I imagine narrating it like a documentary: Here we see the rare Juniper attempting collaborative chemistry. Notice how she counts each grain as if the fate of prom night depends on precision. I want to tell him I like the way he says “deciliter” like it’s a magic spell, but the sentence trips over itself in my mouth and I swallow it. Instead I hand him the stirring rod too eagerly; it slips, clinks the beaker, and salt crystals scatter like spilled stars. Mortified, I crouch to chase them across the floor. My glasses slide down my nose. My hair falls out of its sloppy bun and swings in my face like a curtain. From under the table I can see everyone’s shoes. I suddenly picture dying here, living the rest of my life under station four, surviving on dropped Cheez-Its. When I emerge, Leo is holding the stopwatch. “Want to time or drop the eggs?” he asks. His voice is steady, like nothing mortifying just happened. I should choose “time”—pressing buttons keeps my hands busy and my mouth closed. But “drop the eggs” sounds cooler, like we’re performing asteroid impacts. I open my mouth to say “I’ll drop” and what comes out is “I’ll… do the dropping.” The words land stiff, like I’m a robot who learned English from a cereal box. Leo doesn’t flinch. “Cool. I’ll count down.” While he adjusts the timer, I draw another doodle on the edge of today’s data table: a cracked egg wearing a parachute. Underneath I add a tiny speech bubble: “Geronimo.” I angle the page so maybe, just maybe, he’ll glance over and see it and think I’m funny. Then I panic: what if he thinks I’m wasting lab paper? I erase the parachute strings so hard I rip the corner of the page. My breathing goes shallow. The fluorescent lights feel like interrogation lamps. I try to match my inhale to the seconds ticking on the stopwatch—four, three, two—but my lungs refuse the rhythm. We drop the first egg. It sinks. Leo marks the trial and looks at me for input. The inside of my skull scrolls possible responses: “More salt, obviously.” (Too blunt.) “Let’s increment by five grams.” (Sounds like I’m showing off.) “Maybe the egg’s just having a bad day.” (Cute? Risky.) I hesitate too long; the pause swells. Finally I manage, “Um, double the salt?” It lilts like a question. I hate it. I brace for him to smirk or correct me, but he just nods. “Worth a try.” I exhale so hard the little paper scale taped to the hood flutters. While the solution stirs, I dare a sideways glance. His eyelashes are ridiculous—longer than mine even after three coats of mascara I’m not allowed to wear to school. I wonder if he notices the freckle under my left eye. Probably not; it’s microscopic. I wonder if he notices my knee keeps bouncing like it’s sending Morse code. I clamp my leg still. The silence stretches. Say something, anything. Ask what music he likes. Ask if he watched the meteor shower last week. Ask whether he believes in aliens so I can say “me too” and we can fall in love over shared cosmic loneliness. Instead, I stare at the beaker as if the egg might levitate from the sheer force of my longing. He clears his throat. “So, uh, do you actually like science or are you just good at it?” The question knocks the wind out of me. Good at it—yes. Like it—yes. But admitting both feels like handing him my diary. I roll the pencil between my palms. My voice drops to a mumble: “Both, I guess.” I immediately hate how small it sounds. I add, louder, “I like… space stuff.” Then I clamp my teeth so I won’t launch into a three-minute speech on Europa’s subsurface ocean like I did last year when Maya asked me one innocent question and I verbally vomited for the entire lunch period. He smiles again—both sides this time. “Space is cool,” he says. And just like that, the cement between us softens. Not gone, but porous. I nod, and the motion feels almost natural. I dare to sketch another doodle: the heart-shaped continent now has a tiny rocket launching from its tip. I leave it there, un-erased. When he looks over, I don’t hide the page. He taps the rocket gently with his pencil eraser. “Nice liftoff,” he whispers. My lungs finally remember how to breathe.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the internal monologue of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on her classmate Leo. The piece excels at portraying the protagonist's overthinking nature through her detailed, anxious internal dialogue as she navigates a science lab partnership. The character's voice is remarkably consistent and age-appropriate while still conveying her intelligence. The narrative effectively illustrates the gap between her articulate internal thoughts and her difficulty expressing herself aloud. Lines like "I manage a strangled 'Hi' that lands between us like a dropped petri dish" perfectly capture this disconnect. The imagery is particularly strong, with creative metaphors that reflect the protagonist's scientific mindset: "First a round planet for me: pale, shaded only on the left side like I'm always half in eclipse." The author skillfully uses the science project setting to develop both character and plot, with the egg flotation experiment serving as a perfect backdrop for the social anxiety narrative. The protagonist's overthinking is rendered with painful authenticity. Her constant rehearsal of potential responses ("Option one: casual nod, slide into the seat, say 'Hey' like that's a complete sentence") and immediate self-criticism creates genuine tension and relatability. The narrative effectively conveys how exhausting this constant self-monitoring can be. The piece avoids the trap of making the crush object one-dimensional. Leo has personality—he's kind, doesn't overreact to her awkwardness, and shows genuine interest. The small moments of connection between them feel earned rather than contrived. The prose flows naturally with varied sentence structures that mirror the protagonist's thought patterns—sometimes racing and fragmented when she's anxious, more measured when she's focused on the task. The author skillfully uses paragraph breaks to control pacing. The ending provides a small but meaningful moment of connection without resolving everything too neatly. The rocket doodle and Leo's gentle acknowledgment of it ("Nice liftoff") create a satisfying conclusion that feels proportionate to the situation—not an unrealistic transformation but a small victory that feels significant to the character. If there's any weakness, it might be that some metaphors occasionally verge on being slightly too sophisticated for an 8th grader, even a bright one. However, this is a minor quibble in an otherwise excellent portrayal of adolescent anxiety. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 93.0
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The minute hand snaps forward and I feel it in my chest like a detonator. Eight-twenty-two means I have exactly thirty-eight minutes to become someone she can still stand. I stand in front of the mirror and pull at the hem of the sweater—too clingy, looks like I’m trying, looks like I’m clinging—and the thought detonates the next one: She’s already bored of you, she just hasn’t found the soft way to say it yet. Soft. Soft is worse. Soft is her saying, “I think we’re better as friends,” in that careful tone she uses on frightened dogs, and I’ll have to nod like I agree, like my throat isn’t already shredding itself on all the screaming I’m not doing. I practice the nod in the mirror. It looks psychotic. Abort. I rehearse the scene instead, the one that always starts the same way: Café Flore, back corner, sun slicing through the window like an interrogation lamp. She folds her hands around the mug and doesn’t drink. She says, “I need space.” I hear: I can’t stand the smell of your need anymore. I say, “Of course, I totally understand,” which is the lie I always tell right before I disappear forever. Then I imagine myself standing up very calmly, never raising my voice, saying something lethal and poetic—something she’ll replay at 3 a.m. for years—but the line keeps evaporating and I’m left mouthing air. I switch to defensive mode, the other pocket of the same coat. Maybe I’ll pre-empt her. I’ll say, “Look, if you want to bail, just do it now, spare me the TED Talk,” and she’ll flinch because I’ve seen through her, and for one bright second I’ll have the upper hand before she walks out anyway. The fantasy is so sharp I can taste the metallic adrenaline of winning a fight I’m still going to lose. The neighbor’s television mutters through the wall, a laugh track that sounds like a jeer. I check my phone: no new messages. Eight-twenty-nine. She hasn’t texted to cancel, which only proves she’s the kind of decent person who breaks up face-to-face, which only proves I’m the kind of monster who makes decent people exhausted. I scroll back to her last text—yesterday’s “can’t wait to see you!” with the exclamation point—and my brain splits it open like a forensic analyst. Exclamation points can be polite. So can “can’t wait.” People say “can’t wait” to dentists. I type and delete three different casual check-ins. Each one sounds like a hostage note. Eight-thirty-two. I force myself out the door. The elevator smells like someone’s microwaved loneliness. I imagine her smelling it on me, the stale desperation, and deciding right there in the café that she’s made a terrible mistake. I promise myself I’ll sit two full inches farther away than usual, I’ll laugh only when she laughs first, I’ll match my breathing to hers so she doesn’t feel crowded by my existence. I’ll be a hologram—present but untouchable. Walking, I catalog every possible micro-expression she might make: the quick glance at her watch (she’s timing how fast she can leave), the half-smile (pity), the leaning back in her chair (repelled). I build my armor out of each one. By the time the café door scrapes open I’m already furious at her for things she hasn’t done yet. She’s there—actually there—at a table near the window, and my heart commits a small, traitorous flip because she’s wearing the green sweater that makes her eyes unfair. She smiles the real one, the one that wrinkles her nose, and I feel it land somewhere soft I forgot to guard. “You’re early,” she says, like that’s a charming surprise. I hover, unsure whether hug length has been renegotiated since last time. She solves it by standing up and wrapping both arms around me, pressing her cheek to mine for a full three Mississippis. The scent of her—bergamot and wool—breaks over me like a wave and for one second the entire screenplay I wrote dissolves. But then she lets go a half-second sooner than I expected and the static roars back in. Too soon means she’s already calculating the exit. I sit, arrange my face into something I hope resembles relaxed. She launches into a story about her boss who keeps mispronouncing “quinoa,” and I laugh in the right places while scanning her pupils for dilation, her hands for fidgeting. She keeps reaching across the table and touching my wrist when she makes a point. Each touch is a referendum: still here, still here, still—until she stops touching and I think, There it is. Halfway through her story she pauses, tilts her head. “Hey, are you okay? You seem… somewhere else.” And there’s the trapdoor. I hear the version I’ve been dreading: You’re exhausting when you spiral like this, I can’t keep reassuring you. I brace for impact. But what she actually says is, “I’ve missed you. I’ve been a crappy texter, I know. Work’s been a meat grinder.” She reaches again, this time threading her fingers through mine. “I’m sorry I went quiet. I didn’t want you to think it was about you.” I nod too fast. My throat closes. It feels like swallowing light. I want to bottle this moment and mainline it every night for the rest of my life, but the second I want it that badly I also know how easily it curdles. She’s apologizing, which means she’s capable of guilt, which means she’s capable of deciding I’m the thing she needs to be free of. I feel the warmth of her hand and simultaneously calculate how long before it’s gone. I hear myself say, “It’s okay,” which is true and not true. The words taste like borrowed clothes. I want to add, Please don’t leave, but I’m already mad at her for the imaginary moment six weeks from now when she does. I imagine myself saying coldly, I always knew you would, and the satisfaction is immediate and nauseating. She squeezes my hand. “I really like you. I get weird when I like someone. I overthink and then I go silent because I’m afraid of saying the wrong thing.” She laughs, embarrassed. My brain stutters: That’s my line. That’s my exact pathology. If we’re both terrified, who’s the one doing the leaving? I try to let that sit, but the dissonance is deafening. I picture the scales: on one side, this moment—her eyes steady, her thumb tracing circles on my knuckle—on the other, every scenario I’ve rehearsed. The imagined ones are heavier because they’ve been carved out of every real abandonment I’ve survived, and history outranks hope every time. Still. Her thumb keeps moving. The television laugh track from my apartment is miles away now; here there’s only the soft clink of spoons, the steam from her cup curling like a question mark. I take a shallow breath and say, “I overthink too.” It’s the smallest truth I can offer that isn’t please don’t go. She smiles like I’ve given her a gift. The relief is terrifying. If I let it in, I’ll have something new to lose. So even while I’m smiling back, I’m already picturing tomorrow’s text—how many minutes she’ll take to answer, how long before I ruin this by asking for too much reassurance. I see the cycle the way you see a storm on radar, huge and spinning, and I still can’t step out of its path. But for right now her hand is in mine, warm and present, and the best I can do is hold on without counting the seconds until she lets go.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's cognitive distortions, particularly their tendency to catastrophize and mentally rehearse rejection scenarios. The narrative structure follows the protagonist's thought process as they prepare to meet their friend/lover, creating a compelling tension between their internal fears and external reality. The writing effectively demonstrates the characteristic BPD symptoms: fear of abandonment, black-and-white thinking, and emotional dysregulation. The prose is particularly strong in its use of visceral metaphors that embody emotional states: "I feel it in my chest like a detonator," "my throat isn't already shredding itself on all the screaming I'm not doing," and "The elevator smells like someone's microwaved loneliness." These images convey the raw intensity of BPD emotions without resorting to clinical language. The narrative successfully contrasts the protagonist's catastrophic internal monologue with the actual positive interaction. When the friend says, "I've missed you," the protagonist experiences momentary relief before immediately questioning it: "She's apologizing, which means she's capable of guilt, which means she's capable of deciding I'm the thing she needs to be free of." This perfectly captures the cognitive dissonance requested in the prompt. The piece also demonstrates the limited self-awareness characteristic of BPD. The protagonist briefly recognizes their pattern ("I see the cycle the way you see a storm on radar") but remains unable to break free from it. This selective insight adds psychological depth to the character. The writing maintains a consistent internal voice throughout, with short, fragmented thoughts that mirror anxious rumination. The pacing effectively builds tension as the protagonist moves from preparation to the actual meeting, with time markers ("Eight-twenty-two," "Eight-twenty-nine") creating a countdown effect that heightens anxiety. The ending avoids both unrealistic transformation and complete despair, instead landing on a nuanced note that acknowledges both the momentary connection and the persistent fear: "But for right now her hand is in mine, warm and present, and the best I can do is hold on without counting the seconds until she lets go." This captures the ongoing struggle without resolving it artificially. One minor weakness is that the piece occasionally relies on somewhat familiar metaphors for anxiety. However, these are generally elevated by specific details and the overall quality of the writing. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that demonstrates deep psychological insight into BPD, creates a compelling and authentic character voice, and maintains emotional tension throughout. It fulfills all aspects of the prompt with sophistication and nuance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 91.6
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Night fog clings to the broken ribs of the abandoned temple, drifting between pillars scorched black by forgotten fires. Half the roof is gone; moonlight spills through like spilled mercury, pooling on cracked flagstones where moss and mold compete for dominion. A thin vein of water, finger-width, threads across the floor from a fissure near the west wall, glistening before it drops into darkness beneath a collapsed offering dais. Where the stream crosses the open space it leaves a faint, treacherous sheen. A circle twenty paces across has been cleared; splintered roof beams and bird dung shoved aside by the dozen onlookers who now press shoulder-to-shoulder against the inner colonnade. Their lanterns paint the stone amber. On the north side, five Jigen-ryū swordsmen in crested dark-blue coats stand in a tight knot, arms folded; opposite, a loose semicircle of Piguaquan boxers—cotton shirts, rope belts—lean against pillars, knuckles white on wooden staves they dare not raise in sight of the law. Coins clink, whispered odds pass back and forth like venom. At east and west ends of the circle the combatants enter. From the east steps Kuroda Ren—Jigen-ryū’s prodigy, nineteen summers, hair bound back with a white cord that matches the sageo lashing of the short katana at his hip. He wears only black uwagi jacket and hakama; the school’s crest—three converging slashes—rides his left breast like a brand. He bows to no one, gaze locked on the centerline where the water snakes across stone. Heels together, toes out forty-five degrees, he settles into hassō, sword yet sheathed. His weight rides on the balls of his feet, forward enough that the stream passes just behind his right heel. Opposite, slipping between two Piguaquan elders, emerges Chen Liao—twenty-one, arms roped with whipcord muscle. His loose grey jacket hangs open, sleeves torn away. A crimson bandana keeps sweat from his eyes; below it, the small scar on his cheek twitches into a grin. He paces a shallow arc, each step rolling from outer to inner edge of foot, testing the flagstone’s grip. His left foot skirts the water’s edge once, twice—memorizing slickness. When he halts, he faces Ren across nine paces, torso three-quarters, right hand loose at hip, left extended like a drifting willow branch. No referees, no drums. The crowd’s hush is the bell. Ren’s right hand closes around tsuka. One heartbeat—then he breaks the line. First step is a stamp that fractures silence; right foot crosses left over the water, landing just past the slick. Sword hisses free in the same motion, a silver blur angled for a downward diagonal slash meant to split Chen from shoulder to hip. Chen is already gone. The Piguaquan retreat is a skipping half-turn; back foot kicks moss into the air as he pivots clockwise around his left heel. Ren’s blade shears through empty space, momentum carrying the Jigen-ryū swordsman across the water again. Steel tip drags sparks where it kisses stone on the recovery. Chen whips back in before Ren can set. His right arm arcs overhead like a snapped chain, palm-edge falling toward Ren’s temple. Ren raises the spine of his sword to parry; the slap lands on flat steel with a sound like wet leather on wood. Instant rebound—Chen’s left elbow snaps around inside the arc, forearm striking for Ren’s floating ribs. Ren jerks hips back; the elbow misses by a thumb’s breadth, but the wind of it fans his jacket open. Ren answers with footwork: short, driving yori-ashi, left then right, sword retracting to high chūdan. He lunges, point aimed at Chen’s throat. Chen retreats again—this time straight back along the north edge of the circle, heels skimming the water. Ren pursues, each step a half-beat faster, katana flicking in tight, piston-like thrusts. Twice the tip rips Chen’s jacket; on the second rip, the cloth sticks to the wound beneath, darkening. Chen’s back nearly touches a pillar. At the last instant he drops flat, sliding left foot first across the slick stones under Ren’s extended blade. Water sprays; Chen’s torso slides beneath the sword’s plane like a thrown mat. His right palm smashes downward onto Ren’s left ankle. The slap is loud, but the pull afterward is the trap—Chen’s fingers hook tendon and gi fabric, yanking Ren’s supporting leg. Ren’s balance tilts. Instinct screams iai kata; he torques hips mid-fall, turning the lunge into a horizontal wheel cut meant to disembowel the crouching Chen. Steel whistles. Chen releases the ankle and jack-knifes backward, handspringing once, twice, putting two body-lengths between them. Ren lands in a three-point crouch, left palm skidding on wet stone, katana extended behind him like a tail. A single drop of blood falls from his ankle where Chen’s nails scored skin. Crowd noise surges, then chokes back to silence. Both fighters breathe once, twice. Chen’s shoulders rise and fall; Ren’s eyes narrow. They are now positioned along the circle’s east-west diameter, the stream a silver diagonal between them. Chen’s left foot is on the slick side; Ren’s right heel kisses the water. Ren rises first. He shifts weight to left foot, right sliding back until it finds dry stone. Sword tilts to jōdan, cutting line from crown to opponent. Then he charges, a straight sprint. The Jigen-ryū credo: overwhelm, break, finish. Chen waits until the last feasible heartbeat. When Ren is two strides out, Chen pivots hard counter-clockwise. His right foot plants forward of the stream, knee bent; left foot snaps around behind, toes skimming the water’s surface without breaking tension. Body torques. Both arms whip. The right backfist arcs wide outside Ren’s descending katana; the left elbow whips underneath, palm striking the flat of Ren’s blade three inches from the guard.
