+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 91.0
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**SCP-7234: “The Antecedent Ledger”** **Object Class:** Keter **Special Containment Procedures:** A global early-warning net (Protocol “Quiet Knock”) is to monitor demolition notices, urban-exploration forums, and municipal blight databases for any mention of “a pale door that glows.” When SCP-7234-1 manifests, Mobile Task Force Psi-8 (“Palimpsest”) is to secure the site under cover of hazardous-material remediation, recover all removable documentation, and install an opaque Faraday cage around the aperture. Under no circumstances is the interior to be mapped; on-site navigational equipment is to be disabled or rotated to prevent triangulation. If personnel encounter entities designated SCP-7234-2, pursuit beyond 30 m is forbidden. All recovered papers are to be photographed, bar-coded, and transferred to Site-19 Deep Archive within six hours. Physical originals are to be incinerated; partial copies retained for study must be stored in triple-sealed lead boxes lined with amnestics. O5 Oversight Memorandum 7234-Echo (eyes-only, Level 5/7234) establishes that any Council member found to have entered SCP-7234 without unanimous approval is to be considered a containment breach and detained by the Ethics Committee until further notice. **Description:** SCP-7234 is an extradimensional archive accessible through SCP-7234-1: featureless, paint-blistered wooden doors, 2.13 m high, that manifest inside abandoned or condemned structures worldwide. The doors emit a faint bioluminescent bleed (≤0.3 lux) visible only in total darkness. Attempting to open an SCP-7234-1 instance while lit produces an empty closet; in darkness, the same motion leads to SCP-7234. The archive is a single, continuous hall of indeterminate length composed of grey basalt and oxidized brass lattice. Shelves rise in Escher-like loops, defying vertical load-bearing logic and gravitational orientation. Fluorescent fungi provide dim cyan light. Ambient temperature is 11 °C; relative humidity is 47 %. No life forms native to baseline Earth have been recorded inside, save for SCP-7234-2. SCP-7234-2 are humanoid figures in olive-green biohazard suits fitted with respirators of unknown manufacture. Each suit’s visor is opaque black glass. Entities move silently, removing entire shelving units by unknown means and retreating through darkened archways that seal without trace. When approached within 15 m, SCP-7234-2 sprint at ~35 km/h, vanish behind any obstruction larger than 0.5 m, and do not reappear on thermal imaging. None has been successfully intercepted. Documents within SCP-7234 are labeled in 41 languages, 12 of which have no known correlate. Paper stock varies from papyrus to polymer film, yet carbon-dating yields ages between 210 and 9,400 years. Ink analysis shows formulations not commercially available before or after 19██. Recurring themes include: - A prior global civilization (“Antecedent Culture”) that possessed containment infrastructure of scope equal to or exceeding the Foundation’s. - A “Cascade Breach” dated year “0 A.F.” (After Failure). - References to an organization titled “The Keepers of the Last Threshold,” colloquially “The Foundation,” with sigils identical to the modern SCP Foundation’s. - Personnel files for every current Foundation employee, including D-Class, with recruitment dates centuries prior to their recorded births. **Addendum 7234-1: Initial Penetration Log** *Exploration Team: MTF Psi-8 (“Palimpsest”) – Lt. A. Gomez, Dr. H. Voss, Agent R. Singh* *Date: 2023-11-03* *Entry Point: Abandoned textile mill, Łódź, Poland* [Begin Log] 00:00 – Door pried open. Darkness beyond. A faint glow escapes through the door’s edges in complete darkness. 00:03 – Headlamps fail. IR shows 200 m corridor lined with shelves. 00:10 – First document retrieved. Title: “CLASS A EYES ONLY – OVERSEER DIRECTORY.” Lists O5-1 through O5-13, biometric signatures matching present Council. Entry for O5-7 annotated, “Last seen in Archive Section 7-G, 3 A.F.” 00:21 – Motion detected 50 m starboard. Three SCP-7234-2 entities push wheeled crates. Singh attempts verbal contact; entities retreat behind shelving, crates vanish with them. 00:32 – Voss photographs shelf segment. Labels in English: “SCP-████ – Neutralized via Causal Redaction.” Object number corresponds to an SCP currently in containment at Site-81. Timestamp: “12 A.F.” 00:45 – Structural anomaly: corridor loops back on itself; exit door now 15 m overhead, rotated 90°. GPS shows null coordinates. 01:00 – Lt. Gomez orders retreat. Door reappears at ground level once darkness restored. Team egresses; door disintegrates into sawdust within 30 s. [End Log] **Addendum 7234-2: Selected Recovered Documents** Document A – “Cascade After-Action Report” (Translated from Linear B script): “…the sky cracked at seven loci. The memetic kill switched on. Seventeen hours later, no sapient thought remained uncolonized. The Last Threshold sealed itself against its own architects. All records relocated to Archive to await the next world’s caretakers.” Document B – Personnel File: Name: Dr. █████ ████ Position: Senior Memeticist, Site-19 Recruitment Date: 3 A.F. Notes: “Survived Cascade by hiding in conceptual dead zone. Re-hired 1993 under false identity. Must not remember previous tenure.” Document C – “O5 Visitation Ledger” (handwritten): “O5-2 – 17 A.F. – ‘To verify continuity.’ O5-5 – 21 A.F. – ‘To salt the timeline.’ O5-12 – 29 A.F. – ‘To retrieve proof that we were warned.’” **Addendum 7234-3: Exploration Echo Log** *Team: MTF Mu-4 (“Debuggers”) – Capt. J. Li, Agent K. Okafor* *Date: 2024-04-19* *Entry Point: Derelict mall, Gary, Indiana* [Begin Log] 00:05 – Corridor width fluctuates between 3 m and 11 m without transition. 00:11 – Li notes fresh boot prints in fungal dust: “Five sets, size 12, Vibram sole – Foundation-issue.” Prints lead deeper, none return. 00:18 – Discovery of chamber labeled “Restricted – Level 6.” Door ajar. Inside: conference table, 13 chairs, one overturned. Mug still warm; contents match Site-01 cafeteria coffee (verified by isotope ratio). 00:22 – Okafor finds handwritten note on headed paper: “We did it to stop them from doing it to stop us. —O5-3.” Paper age: 6 minutes. 00:29 – Both agents report sudden onset déjà vu and intrusive memory of dying in a previous timeline. Li’s heart rate spikes to 180 bpm. 00:32 – SCP-7234-2 squad (seven entities) enters chamber. They freeze on sighting agents, then produce cylindrical devices emitting total darkness. Okafor tackles one; suit fabric tears, revealing nothing inside—costume hangs empty. Entities escape while lights are out. 00:37 – Li attempts to follow; corridor beyond chamber replaced by blank basalt wall. Coffee mug now cold, dust layer undisturbed as if never touched. [End Log] **Incident 7234-Theta** On 2024-05-01, security drones inside Site-01 recorded O5-7 accessing an SCP-7234-1 instance that had manifested in Sublevel 5 archival vault (previously inspected and declared clear). Surveillance lost signal at 00:13. At 00:27, O5-7 re-emerged carrying a manila folder marked “Project Tehom – Iteration 6.” Folder contents were incinerated by O5-7 personally before questioning could occur. Ethics Committee investigation pending. **Addendum 7234-4: Forecast Model** Foundation probabilistic engine Delphi-9 projects 78 % likelihood that SCP-7234 will, within 12 months, manifest inside an active Foundation site. Model also predicts a 41 % probability that removal of archive contents by SCP-7234-2 is accelerating toward a “Null Archive” event. Definition of Null Archive: total erasure of documentary evidence that the Antecedent Culture or the Cascade ever occurred, possibly precipitating a second Cascade. Containment upgrade to Apollyon under review. **Note from Dr. Voss, Site-19 Archivist:** “We keep telling ourselves we’re the first line of defense. The paper doesn’t lie—just our memories do. One day that door will open under fluorescent lights and still lead inside. And when it does, we’ll find our own fingerprints already in the dust.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates a strong understanding of the SCP Foundation format and tone. The response creates a compelling anomaly that perfectly fits the prompt requirements: unmarked doors in abandoned buildings leading to an impossible archive containing evidence of a previous civilization and unauthorized O5 Council visits. The piece excels in its technical execution of the SCP format, including containment procedures, description, exploration logs, and recovered document excerpts. The clinical tone shifts appropriately to more personal perspectives in the exploration logs, maintaining the characteristic SCP blend of bureaucratic documentation and horror. The concept of "The Antecedent Ledger" is particularly strong - the idea that the current Foundation is merely the latest iteration following a catastrophic "Cascade Breach" creates an effective existential horror element. The details about personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago and the O5 Council's secret visits add layers of conspiracy and intrigue. The exploration logs effectively build tension through the discovery of increasingly disturbing information. The hazmat-suited entities (SCP-7234-2) that flee when approached are well-integrated, and the revelation that they're empty suits adds a surreal element. The writer skillfully incorporates small details that enhance the atmosphere - warm coffee mugs, boot prints in fungal dust, and the eerie note "We did it to stop them from doing it to stop us." The prose is appropriately clinical in the formal sections while allowing for more immediate description in the logs. The writer demonstrates excellent control of pacing, revealing information gradually while maintaining mystery. The final note from Dr. Voss provides a perfect closing that encapsulates the existential dread of the piece. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overreliance on SCP tropes and a few instances where the technical jargon becomes slightly excessive. The piece could have explored the psychological impact on researchers more deeply, though this is a minor critique given the format constraints. Overall, this is an exemplary SCP entry that demonstrates mastery of the format, creates genuine cosmic horror, and fulfills all the prompt requirements with creativity and skill. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The city was called Umi—an old word, the guide had said, meaning both “mother” and “deep water.” From the Residence windows it looked orderly: terraced roofs the color of wet sand, bougainvillea trained along white walls, the slow silver arc of the river turning glassy in the evening. Yet order, Kael reflected, is the first story any place tells about itself. The second story is what you learn when you walk alone. They left the Residence at the slack hour after the ceremonial lunch, slipping past the guards with the ease of a childhood spent in embassies where doors were never meant for children. Officially Kael was resting; officially the next meeting was not until the tide turned at dawn. Unofficially, a hunger had woken that no kitchen in the Residence could satisfy. The market lay in the delta between two arms of the river, where the air smelled of brine and fermenting fruit. Because Umi was a port, its people had kept the old tongues and invented new ones. Kael heard vowels lengthened like stretched silk, heard consonants softened until they resembled the wash of waves. Here the divergence of the lineages was not an abstract briefing note: it was visible in wrists too slender for Earth gravity, in the sheen of skin that held a subtle aquamarine even under the red sun, in eyes whose pupils opened vertically like those of cats. Children of the Third Lineage ran between the stalls, their ankles jointed higher, their laughter skirling above the drone of haggling. A woman lifted a bolt of cloth the color of stormcloud lit from beneath. The pigment was called tiri, she told Kael, made from mollusks that drank the runoff of volcanic springs. It could not be fixed anywhere else; on Earth it dulled to gray within weeks. She spread it across her palms, and Kael saw how the hue shifted, opaline, as if remembering watery depths. Protocol said not to buy anything: gifts create obligations. Kael bought a narrow scarf, paid in the local shells that passed for coin, and tucked it inside the sleeve of their formal coat. The woman smiled—not the smile of a vendor but of someone who recognizes kinship of a complicated sort. Farther on, a circle of listeners had gathered around an old man perched on a salt crate. His voice was low, almost a chant. He spoke of the days before the Separation Edict, when ships still arrived every month from the Orbital guilds, carrying people who called themselves simply human and expected the name to work like a passport. “They measured our skulls,” the old man said, “and when the numbers came out wrong they wrote correction on the forms.” The crowd murmured, not in anger but in the rhythm of a story worn smooth by retelling. Kael felt the brief burn of inherited guilt, then something more useful: curiosity. They circled back along the wharf, where boats with ribbed sails rocked at anchor. A youth sat mending nets, fingers moving with the absent grace of long practice. Kael asked what fish ran in this season. The youth looked up, eyes black and glossy as obsidian. “The kind that carry maps in their bones,” he said. “When you eat them, you remember places you’ve never been.” A fisher’s joke, perhaps, but Kael tasted the salt air and wondered what else might be ingested whole. By the time the Residence lights loomed above the garden wall, the sky had gone the bruised violet that passes for night here. Kael climbed the service stair, the scarf trailing from a pocket like a smuggled dream. In the corridor outside their suite stood Commander Reeve, arms crossed, uniform immaculate. “Envoy,” Reeve said without greeting, “you have been absent.” “I walked,” Kael answered. The word sounded small in the hush of carpet and conditioned air. “You walked,” Reeve repeated, giving the syllable the weight of a dropped anchor. “Minister Arden requests your company. Now.” Minister Arden’s office occupied the eastern wing, overlooking the same river Kael had crossed hours earlier. The view was framed by data panes alive with scrolling metrics—grain yields, birth ratios, solar flare probabilities. Arden stood with his back to them, a silhouette against graphs. He was tall even for a First Lineage man, his hair braided in the style that here denoted neither gender nor office but endurance: each bead marked a year of elected silence. “Offworlder,” he said, turning. His face was broad, planed by ancestry and weather. “You left the safety of protocol.” “I wanted the smell of the city,” Kael said. “Smell,” Arden mused. “An under-rated sense. Command fears it will mislead you.” He gestured toward a chair; remained standing himself. “Tell me: what did you smell?” “Mollusk dye. Net tar. The river’s memory of rain.” Kael paused. “And something like regret.” Arden’s eyes narrowed, not unfriendly. “Regret is a luxury here. We prefer consequence.” He tapped a pane; the river vanished, replaced by a pedigree chart that branched like coral. “Every Lineage claims its traits arose naturally. Yet the records show interventions—some accidental, some less so. We are what our grandparents chose under pressure. What do you make of that, Envoy?” “That choice is never finished,” Kael said. A flicker in Arden’s expression—approval or its opposite, hard to read. “Command wants three concessions before the treaty is signed. One: unrestricted migration for Firsts. Two: orbital control of weather platforms. Three—” he held up a hand to forestall protest—“a genomic census, to ensure no ‘unstable variants’ arise.” Kael felt the scarf’s soft weight against their wrist. “You speak as if the variants were orchards to prune.” “The metaphors are theirs,” Arden said, nodding toward the window where the Residence’s floodlights paled the stars. “I merely translate.” “And if I refuse the translation?” “Then you will be replaced. Another envoy, less curious about smells.” Arden leaned closer; Kael caught the faint scent of cedar and iodine. “But curiosity has its uses. The census—yes, it is a blade. Yet a blade may be turned. I need someone who has walked the market alone, who carries tiri in their sleeve, who knows regret is not the same as surrender.” The room’s lights dimmed automatically, emulating dusk. Somewhere below, the river continued its ancient argument with gravity. “What do you want from me?” Kael asked. “A question that risks an honest answer,” Arden said. “Stay the night. Sit with my people—the ones without titles—and listen until your ears change shape. Then tell Command what you heard. If your report differs from mine, perhaps both our worlds will have to listen.” He extended a hand. It was the first time anyone on this planet had offered the gesture. Kael took it, feeling the callus of a palm that had hauled nets in a youth Arden never spoke of. Outside, the tide turned. In the Residence corridors, screens flickered with unread communiqués, but here, in the quiet, Kael felt the slow swing of something larger—an equilibrium not yet decided, like the pigment in the woman’s cloth, still finding its true color under an alien sun.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures Le Guin's style with its anthropological perspective, measured prose, and focus on cultural differences. The writing demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of how to build a science fiction world through small, telling details rather than exposition. The protagonist Kael is developed effectively as a diplomatic envoy with curiosity that extends beyond official channels. Their decision to slip away from the Residence shows both character and advances the plot naturally. The interactions in the market provide rich cultural context about the divergent human lineages, showing rather than telling the reader about this world's history and tensions. The prose is elegant without becoming overwrought. Descriptions like "vowels lengthened like stretched silk" and "the river's ancient argument with gravity" demonstrate poetic sensibility while remaining functional. The author skillfully employs sensory details—the smell of "brine and fermenting fruit," the visual quality of the tiri cloth that shifts "opaline, as if remembering watery depths"—to immerse the reader in this alien yet familiar setting. The dialogue, particularly in the confrontation with Minister Arden, is nuanced and layered with subtext. Lines like "Regret is a luxury here. We prefer consequence" efficiently communicate cultural differences while revealing character. The conversation effectively tests the envoy's "wits and will" as requested in the prompt. The piece does have minor weaknesses. The transition from the market back to the Residence feels slightly rushed. Commander Reeve appears briefly but isn't fully utilized as a character. While the ending effectively sets up tension between competing interests, it could perhaps benefit from a slightly stronger concluding note that more definitively captures the envoy's internal decision or realization. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that successfully emulates Le Guin's thoughtful approach to science fiction, where cultural anthropology and political tensions are explored through personal encounters and sensory experience rather than exposition. The writing demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of how to build a science fiction world through small, telling details. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
