+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The phone screen says 12 % like it’s judging me. I shove it deeper into my jean jacket—like that’ll shut it up—and look around. New Orleans smells like beer that’s been baked into the sidewalk. I’ve never been anywhere this loud this early; the air’s already vibrating with some trumpet that’s probably blocks away but feels like it’s coming from inside my skull. Okay, Taylor, inventory check: one half-crushed pack of Camels I don’t remember stealing, forty-three dollars and a handful of change, a hoodie that smells like my stepdad’s truck (and I hate that I still think of it as his truck), and a dead name in my back pocket like a ticket stub I can’t throw away because maybe I’ll need it for something. The ride that dumped me here—some stoner with a Jesus fish on his bumper who spent the last fifty miles calling me “little lady”—peeled off toward the river, leaving me on Dauphine with the sun poking me in the eyes. I start walking toward whatever’s louder, because if I stop moving the only thing left to do is think. That’s when I see him: kid about my age, hair dyed the color of antifreeze, hoodie sleeves shredded like he’s been swarmed by angry cats. He’s balancing on the curb outside a Walgreens like he’s surfing the sidewalk. When he spots me staring, he grins like we’ve got a secret. “Nice jacket,” he says. “Vintage or just old?” I snort. “Inherited trauma.” He laughs—sharp, surprised. “I’m Saint.” “Taylor,” I say, and then, because I can’t help it, “with an o-r, not an e-r.” Saint tilts his head. “Noted. You running?” My stomach knots, but what’s the point of lying? “Yeah.” “Cool. Me too.” He flicks his cigarette into the gutter. “You hungry?” I hate that my answer is so quick. “Starving.” We duck into a po-boy shop that smells like grease and forgiveness. Saint orders two shrimp sandwiches and pays with a crumpled twenty like it’s nothing. I try not to look too grateful as I chew. “So what’s your damage?” he asks, mouth half-full. I shrug. “Came out. Family imploded. Figured anywhere was better.” Saint nods like he’s ticking boxes. “They try the praying-away thing?” “And the yelling thing, and the we-love-you-but thing.” I rip my sandwich in half. “You?” He wipes his mouth. “My mom’s boyfriend thinks boundaries are for cowards. Took a beer bottle to the head, woke up deciding I’d rather be homeless than dead.” The bell over the door jingles; a cop walks in for coffee. Saint’s eyes flick up, then down at his fries like they’re suddenly fascinating. I pretend I’m texting, thumb hovering over a black screen. Twelve percent. Not enough for panic, enough for emergency. The cop leaves. Saint exhales. “You got anywhere to crash?” he asks. “Nope.” “Same.” He crumples the sandwich paper. “There’s an abandoned house near the tracks—squatters rotate through. It’s not the Ritz, but the roof’s solid.” I should ask a million questions—like, is it safe, is he safe, are there rats or worse—but the alternative is wandering until dark and figuring it out alone. I stuff the last bite in my mouth and nod. We zigzag through streets that smell like cinnamon and piss. Saint talks the whole time, hands flying. He’s got stories that feel half-truth, half-myth—rooftop parties, a drag queen who gave him eyeliner lessons, a guy named Juju who trades phone chargers for mixtapes. I listen, adding maybe three words, wondering if I’m being recruited or adopted. The house is shotgun style, paint peeling like a bad sunburn. Inside smells like mildew and weed. Two guys asleep on a couch, one girl braiding another girl’s hair in the corner. They look up; Saint lifts a hand. “Fresh meat, don’t spook ’em.” I follow him to a back room with a mattress on the floor and one cracked window. A pile of blankets that might once have been blue. “Home sweet,” Saint says. “You can stash your stuff.” I drop my backpack. “I don’t have stuff.” He grins. “Even easier.” The sun’s starting to dip when we head back out. Saint says we need supplies—water, batteries, luck. I ask about a charger; he says we’ll hunt after dark when the tourists are drunk and careless. Bourbon Street is chaos in fishnets. Trumpet players on every corner, bachelorettes screaming like seagulls. I feel invisible and neon at the same time. Saint weaves us through the crowd like he’s done it every day of his life. At a corner, he stops short. “Shit. That’s Juju.” The guy leaning against a lamppost looks maybe twenty, wearing a sequined blazer and combat boots. His eyes are kind. “Saint, you owe me a tape.” Saint digs in his pocket, pulls out a crushed cassette. “Mixed it myself.” Juju flips it over. “You label this ‘Fuck You Songs’?” “Working title.” Saint jerks a thumb at me. “Taylor needs a charger.” Juju studies me like I’m a complicated chord. “You trustworthy, Taylor?” I open my mouth, shut it. “Ask me tomorrow.” He smiles, slow. “Fair. Come by the record store on Decatur at noon. Bring decent vibes, we’ll trade.” They slap hands like some secret handshake. I’m still trying to breathe. Night drops fast. Streetlights buzz on. Saint buys us canned beans with the last of his cash; we eat them cold on the ferry dock watching barges slide by like steel whales. I check the phone: 8 %. One bar. I hover over Mom’s contact, thumb shaking. If I call, she’ll cry, then she’ll promise to “work on it,” then she’ll ask where I am and I’ll either lie or break completely. Saint watches me. “You don’t have to decide tonight.” “I know.” The word cracks. He leans back on his elbows. “First time I ran, I called my grandma from a gas station. She said, ‘Baby, the door’s always open, but the locks haven’t changed.’ I hung up, puked in the trash can, then kept walking. Best worst night of my life.” I laugh, watery. “Sounds about right.” We head back through quieter streets. The city smells beignet-sweet and river-dirty. My feet hurt; my heart hurts like it’s been bench-pressing dread. In the squat, the others are still up, passing a joint and a battered guitar. Someone hands it to me. I strum three chords I learned off YouTube, wincing at every buzzed string. Saint hums along off-key. At some point, my phone dies completely. The screen just blinks out, no drama, just black. I stare at it like it’s a tiny coffin. Saint nudges me. “You’re still here.” I nod. “Yeah. Guess I am.” He grins, teeth bright in the lamplight. “Welcome to Day One.” I close my eyes. The guitar string under my thumb buzzes but holds. Outside, a train wails like it knows all our names.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a teenage runaway navigating a new environment after coming out as trans. The first-person narration creates immediacy, and the mixed tense works well to convey Taylor's disoriented state of mind. The writing excels at establishing a strong sense of place. New Orleans comes alive through sensory details: "smells like beer that's been baked into the sidewalk," "air's already vibrating with some trumpet," and "streets that smell like cinnamon and piss." These vivid descriptions ground the reader in Taylor's experience. Character development is handled with subtlety. Taylor's internal monologue reveals their vulnerability without becoming melodramatic: "a dead name in my back pocket like a ticket stub I can't throw away because maybe I'll need it for something." The character's conflicting emotions about their family and situation are conveyed naturally through small moments, like hovering over their mother's contact information. Saint serves as an effective foil - more experienced and seemingly carefree, yet carrying his own trauma. Their developing relationship feels authentic, with Saint neither idealized nor demonized. The secondary characters (Juju and the squatters) add texture without overwhelming the narrative. The dialogue is particularly strong, capturing distinct voices and revealing character through speech patterns. Saint's "What's your damage?" and Taylor's "Inherited trauma" exchange efficiently establishes their dynamic. Conversations feel natural rather than expository. The pacing is well-managed, covering a full day without rushing or dragging. The narrative moves between locations and encounters while maintaining focus on Taylor's emotional journey. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - not falsely optimistic but offering a tentative sense of possibility with "Welcome to Day One." There are a few minor weaknesses. Some metaphors, while evocative, occasionally border on being too clever for a 16-year-old narrator ("barges slide by like steel whales"). The story also relies on some familiar runaway tropes (the abandoned house, the street-smart guide), though it generally handles them with freshness. Overall, this is a compelling and well-crafted piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a distinctive voice and emotionally resonant narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# My Apocalypse Buddy The morning sun filtered through the corrugated iron roof of what had once been a suburban garage and was now, according to the hand-painted sign, "Midas & Chewy's Emporium of Things What Still Work (Mostly)." Midas sat cross-legged on an upturned milk crate, contemplating a map drawn on the back of a cereal box with what appeared to be burnt stick. "Right then, Chewy," he said to the small animatronic koala perched on a nearby shelf. "According to my calculations, the old hardware shop should be approximately three left turns past the burnt-out supermarket, or possibly four right turns past the supermarket that isn't burnt out yet." Chewy's eyes flickered a skeptical amber. "Yes, well, your confidence is noted," Midas replied, folding the map with the sort of precision that suggested he'd once had a job involving paper and the illusion of competence. "But we need nails. The roof's got more holes than a politician's promise, and Mrs. Henderson from number forty-two keeps dropping by to complain about the indoor weather." The koala's eyes shifted to a resigned purple. "What's the worst that could happen?" Midas asked, which was exactly the sort of question that caused small electronic marsupials to develop what might charitably be called anxiety disorders, assuming they weren't already suffering from several centuries of battery degradation and existential dread. --- The journey began promisingly enough. They'd made it nearly two hundred yards before encountering their first complication, which was either a very small sinkhole or a very large pothole that had achieved sentience and developed property rights. "Afternoon," said the pothole, in the tone of something that had been practicing its small talk for several geological eras. "Lovely weather for not falling into me." Midas, who'd learned that politeness cost nothing and often prevented things from eating you, nodded respectfully. "Terribly sorry, we'll just be going around—" "That'll be five bottle caps," said the pothole. "Toll road." "It's a pavement." "Details," said the pothole, which had clearly been reading economics textbooks. They paid with three bottle caps and a button that claimed to have once belonged to someone important, then continued on their way. Chewy's eyes had settled into a sort of worried yellow-green that suggested this was already exceeding his daily recommended allowance of nonsense. The supermarket (burnt-out variety) appeared exactly where Midas hadn't expected it, which was to say it had apparently moved three blocks south since his last expedition. Buildings did that sometimes, usually on Tuesdays. "Left turn here," Midas announced with the confidence of a man who'd once gotten lost in his own bathroom. This was when they discovered that the local neighborhood watch had been taken over by a particularly militant group of garden gnomes who had unionized and developed a fondness for traffic cones. The gnomes, who appeared to have been reading old parking regulations, insisted on directing them through an elaborate system of detours that seemed designed to maximize both confusion and exposure to their gift shop. Forty-seven minutes later, they emerged with a commemorative snow globe, a receipt for directions rendered, and a deep suspicion that the gnomes had been making up street names. "Hardware store should be just past those abandoned cars," Midas said, pointing at what turned out to be a small herd of rust-colored cows. They objected to being called cars with a unanimity that suggested they'd been practicing. The actual hardware store, when they finally found it, had been converted into a very exclusive restaurant by a family of raccoons who'd apparently watched too many cooking shows. The head raccoon, wearing a tiny chef's hat that was definitely stolen from somewhere unfortunate, explained that they could certainly have nails, provided they didn't mind them being served medium-rare with a reduction of something that used to be paint thinner. "Do you have any that aren't on the menu?" Midas asked hopefully. The raccoon conferred with his sous-chefs, which mostly involved a lot of chittering and what sounded like a heated debate about presentation. Eventually, they were offered a small bag of rusty nails in exchange for Chewy's left ear. "Absolutely not," said Midas, which was probably the first sensible thing he'd said all day. Chewy's eyes glowed a grateful blue-green. The negotiation that followed would have impressed medieval diplomats, assuming medieval diplomats had been willing to trade three buttons, a shoelace, and a heartfelt rendition of "Waltzing Matilda" for construction materials. The raccoons seemed particularly moved by the shoelace, which apparently complemented the restaurant's industrial aesthetic. --- The journey home was, if anything, more eventful. The garden gnomes had apparently decided to implement a one-way system that led through a small swamp they'd been cultivating for tax purposes. The swamp, which introduced itself as Gerald, was terribly sorry about the whole sinking thing but had recently discovered the concept of property values and was trying to establish waterfront real estate. "Just a little more to the left," called Midas, who was currently up to his waist in Gerald's northern region while Chewy perched on his shoulder like a very small, very electronic figurehead. "I think I can see the roof from here." This was optimistic, as they were currently facing what appeared to be the remains of a shopping trolley, but optimism was like rust: it spread if you didn't keep an eye on it. Three hours later, they arrived home covered in swamp, smelling faintly of raccoon cuisine, and carrying exactly seventeen nails of dubious structural integrity. Mrs. Henderson was waiting. "About that roof," she began. "Tomorrow," said Midas, who had just discovered that his milk crate had been stolen by something that left tiny footprints and a thank-you note. "Definitely tomorrow." Chewy's eyes flickered a weary amber-green that translated roughly to: *Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow, creeps in this petty pace from day to day, and all our yesterdays have lighted fools the way to dusty death.* "Shakespeare?" Midas asked. The koala's eyes glowed smug purple. "Show-off," said Midas, but he was smiling as he said it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its absurdist humor, anthropomorphic objects, and clever wordplay. The post-technological collapse world is vividly realized through encounters with sentient potholes, militant garden gnomes, and raccoon restaurateurs. The piece begins as instructed with Midas and Chewy deliberating their predicament (a leaky roof) and planning their mission (to get nails). The mission indeed goes sideways in multiple amusing ways, from paying toll to a sentient pothole to negotiating with raccoon chefs. They return home "worse for wear" as requested, covered in swamp and with only seventeen dubious nails to show for their trouble. The characterization is strong. Midas is indeed "hapless" with "a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble," while Chewy communicates through color-changing eyes that express skepticism, resignation, and even literary references. Their relationship feels lived-in and genuine. The prose is particularly strong, with Pratchett-esque turns of phrase like "optimism was like rust: it spread if you didn't keep an eye on it" and humorous asides like buildings moving "usually on Tuesdays." The narrative voice maintains a consistent dry wit throughout. Where the piece could improve is in its structure. While entertaining, the middle section feels somewhat episodic without a strong narrative arc or escalating tension. The encounters, while amusing, don't build upon each other in a way that creates mounting stakes or complications. Additionally, while the ending brings closure to the immediate story, it doesn't provide much resolution to the larger world situation or character development. The dialogue is sparse but effective, particularly in conveying Chewy's personality despite his inability to speak conventionally. The world-building is creative and distinctive, with just enough detail to suggest a much larger and stranger post-apocalyptic landscape without overwhelming the reader. Overall, this is a highly successful response to the prompt, capturing Pratchett's style and the requested narrative elements while creating memorable characters and situations. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Scene: “Hardbacks & Haven”** *Location: The Hayes, Cardiff – a narrow, crooked Victorian bookshop wedged between a closed-down travel agent and a vegan pasty bar.* *Time: 4:23 p.m., slate-grey sky pressing against the mullioned windows, rain like tossed gravel against the glass.* --- **[Bell clangs: an old ship’s bell, not a twee tinkle.]** **Mara (without looking up from the till):** We shut at five. If it’s shelter you want, take it, but the kettle’s already off. **Kit (voice warm as whisky, just inside the door):** I’d settle for sanctuary. And perhaps a paperback shield. Is that treason in a place like this? **Mara (still counting copper):** Only if you dog-ear. Or if you’re the sort that reads the ending first. **Kit (peeling off wet beanie, curls springing like jack-in-the-boxes):** Guilty on both counts, I’m afraid. But I bury the evidence. Professional habit. **Mara (glances up; recognition flickers, is instantly shuttered):** Ah. You’re the one making our pavements unusable this afternoon. I nearly clipped a photographer with the returns trolley. **Kit (hand to chest, mock-wounded):** You wound me on behalf of the tabloids. That’s oddly noble. And you are…? **Mara:** Proprietor. Mara Llewellyn. Also chief duster, reluctant barista, and bouncer of anyone who brings fizzy drinks near the Folio shelf. **Kit (angling toward the counter, raindrops still jewelling his lashes):** Mara. Solid, mythic. I like names you can stand on. Mine’s—well, you probably know. **Mara:** Kit Carrington. Your face is on the side of the Number 62 bus. Hard to miss, even for those of us who walk. **Kit (leans in, conspiratorial):** Between us, the bus version has better lighting. Real me’s a bit… weathered. **Mara:** You’re dripping on C.S. Lewis. That’s the real tragedy. **Kit (steps back, theatrically contrite):** Blasphemy! Let me—here— (He rakes fingers through his hair, flicking droplets. They land in tiny starbursts on the parquet.) Tell me, Mara-of-the-sharp-tongue, what’s the going rate for redemption? A signed first edition? A sonnet recited atop the counter? **Mara (dry):** We price redemption at £9.99, second-hand. Aisle three, next to Self-Help and Regret. **Kit (eyes widening, delighted):** You’re immune. That’s… terrifying. And refreshing. Everyone today has been squealing like I’m Father Christmas with abs. **Mara (snorts):** I’m thirty-three. I’ve outgrown squealing. Also, I never watched your pirate show. **Kit (hand over heart again, this time with actual dent in bravado):** Not even the first series? The one where I swing in shirtless to save Cardiff Castle from French mercenaries? **Mara:** Especially not that one. I was too busy repelling actual mercenaries: university fees. **Kit (quiet, intrigued):** Fair hit. Mind if I orbit while you close up? I’ve got a swarm of lenses outside convinced I’m either eloping or having breakdown number four. **Mara:** Suit yourself. Just don’t rearrange anything. The travel section faces the window for tactical reasons—blocks the worst glare from Specsavers. **Kit (wandering, pulling out a battered Greene):** Brighton Rock. You shelve it under Theology, not Crime. Dark humour or clerical error? **Mara (allowing a small smile):** Read the last page and tell me God’s not the bigger villain. **Kit (turns, eyes glinting):** You’re dangerous. I should leave before you ruin my neatly curated ego. **Mara:** Door’s where you left it. Mind the bell, it bites. **Kit (doesn’t move):** I will, but first— (He flips the book open, thumbs to a dog-eared corner, winces.) Hypothetically, if I bought this and every other bruised copy you’ve got, would that buy me ten minutes of conversation without sarcasm? **Mara (leans on counter, chin in hand):** Sarcasm’s a flat fee. Non-negotiable. But the books are half-price after four on Tuesdays. **Kit:** Today is Tuesday. **Mara (glances at wall clock, sighs):** So it is. You’ve the luck of the Welsh drizzle. **Kit (smiles, slow and crooked):** Luck, or fate? My mum believed in fate. Said the universe would elbow me toward anyone who’d puncture my nonsense. **Mara (soft despite herself):** Your mum sounds sensible. **Kit (voice dips):** She died the year before the pirate nonsense. Missed the circus. Sometimes I think she’d have laughed herself sick, then grounded me for vanity. **Mara (a pause, then quieter):** Loss has a way of editing the spotlight. Makes the shadows sharper. **Kit (meeting her eyes, the charm ebbing into something rawer):** You too? **Mara:** Books are mostly ghosts. I trade in them daily. Dad went ten years ago; left me the lease and a first edition Brontë with half the pages missing. Said the gaps were for me to fill. **Kit (gently closes Greene, places it on counter like an offering):** I can’t fill gaps, but I can listen. And apparently pay £4.50 for the privilege. **Mara (rings it up, fingers brushing his—static snap, both flinch):** That’s the Brontë surcharge. **Kit (grins, fragile edges gone):** Worth the shock. **[Outside, cameras click like distant crickets.]** **Kit (wincing):** They’ll be papping the vegan pasty next. “Star eats cruelty-free at 4:30!” **Mara:** You could leave through the back alley. Door sticks, but it opens onto the market—easy to lose yourself among the spice stalls. **Kit (tilts head):** Come with me. **Mara (laughs, startled):** Absolutely not. I have cash-up, window shutters, and a goldfish to feed. **Kit:** Tomorrow, then. Same drizzle, different excuse. I’ll bring coffee that isn’t instant, and you can pretend you still hate me. **Mara (eyes betraying the first real flicker of heat):** I never said hate. **Kit (soft):** Stubborn, then. I like stubborn. Keeps the ego from floating off like a birthday balloon. **Mara (looks down, cheeks betraying her):** Five minutes. Five. Then the shutters come down, literally and metaphorically. **Kit (leans across counter, voice barely above the rain):** Five is enough. I once conquered Tortuga in three. **Mara:** Cardiff’s not Tortuga. **Kit:** No. It’s better. It’s real. **[The bell gives a half-hearted clink as he steps back, not quite retreating, as Mara resets the till with hands that suddenly don’t quite fit the buttons.]** **Mara (to herself, just audible):** Damn.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively creates a romance scene in a Welsh bookstore between a famous actor and a bookstore owner. The writing demonstrates strong command of dialogue, which carries most of the narrative as requested, revealing character through speech patterns and responses rather than exposition. The actor, Kit, is well-portrayed as charming with a fragile ego. His theatrical gestures, mock-wounded reactions, and persistent attempts to win over Mara demonstrate his need to be liked. The bookstore owner, Mara, maintains a superficial immunity to his charm through her dry wit and sarcasm, which indeed provokes a genuine attraction from Kit who finds her resistance "refreshing." The writer skillfully conveys Mara's inward attraction despite her outward resistance through subtle physical cues like "cheeks betraying her" and hands that "suddenly don't quite fit the buttons." The dialogue is particularly strong, with distinct voices for each character. Kit speaks with theatrical flair and charm ("You wound me on behalf of the tabloids"), while Mara's responses are direct, witty, and slightly sardonic ("We price redemption at £9.99, second-hand. Aisle three, next to Self-Help and Regret"). Their exchange has an authentic rhythm and reveals character through speech rather than description. The setting is economically but vividly established in the opening stage directions, creating a sense of place with details like "slate-grey sky" and "rain like tossed gravel against the glass." The writer uses small physical actions and environmental details to ground the scene while maintaining focus on the dialogue. The piece effectively builds chemistry between the characters, starting with resistance and moving toward connection. The turning point comes naturally when Kit reveals vulnerability about his mother, shifting from charm offensive to genuine connection. This transition feels earned rather than forced. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments of purple prose ("raindrops still jewelling his lashes") and a few instances where the dialogue becomes slightly too clever to be believable. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The iron door groaned inward on hinges that had not tasted oil in a generation, and a breath of colder, older air rolled over Aya’s masked face—grave-cold, cellar-cold, the exhalation of something that had waited far too long. She stepped first, bootheel ringing on basalt flags polished by centuries of illicit traffic. Katra followed, coat-tails sweeping like raven wings; Simeon’s lantern hissed, its whale-oil flame guttering blue, as though reluctant to push back the dark. The corridor beyond was not the chaos of overturned crates and panicked footfalls they had rehearsed for; it was a mausoleum hush. Gas-pipes ran along the vaulted ceiling, brass nozzles coughing out weak, stuttering light. Each spurt of flame etched the ribs of the masonry like the inside of a colossal whale. Shadows lengthened, shrank, lengthened again, as if the darkness itself were breathing. Aya’s pulse beat behind her ears in Morse—*too quiet, too quiet.* Her gloved hand brushed the vial at her wrist—three drops of her own blood suspended in quicksilver, a tether to the immateria. It felt suddenly ridiculous, a parlour trick against whatever calm had settled here. They passed the first archway. Carved stone walruses, tusks lacquered in tar, stared down with empty ruby eyes. Katra muttered, “Even the statues know something’s off.” Simeon only adjusted the strap of his satchel where the dynamite nested like steel eggs. Then the corridor widened into the underhold proper: a circular chamber domed in black brick, iron rings set into the mortar where chains had once moored sea-beasts or prisoners—history did not specify. In the centre, upon a tripod of rusted iron, rested the Scythan relic: a disk of greened bronze, edges serrated like a shark’s jaw, its surface etched with spirals that hurt to follow. Around it, a lattice of copper tubing carried faintly luminous vapour—an etheric ward, engineered by men who trusted brass yet feared the void. The air tasted of ozone and damp wool. And before the relic stood Elzbieta Voss, undisputed master of the Morska guild, very much at liberty. She wore the same cutlass that had slit throats from Björnholm to Port Leviathan, the same high-collared coat of midnight broadcloth, but now her wrists were unmarred by irons. At her flanks stood two guards in oil-stained greatcoats, goggles fogged with breath; each levelled a revolving carbine whose brasswork gleamed like freshly polished coffin handles. Elzbieta’s smile was a scalpel. “Close the door behind you, pet. The draught plays the devil with the lamps.” A dozen thoughts spiked through Aya’s mind—*impossible, informant lied, trap*—but the door clanged shut at Simeon’s back before any could reach her tongue. The sound rang final, a judge’s gavel. Elzbieta tilted her head, auburn curls escaping the knot at her nape. “I was beginning to think you’d keep me waiting till the tide turned. Punctuality is a virtue, Lady Ravencrest.” The name struck Aya like a thrown stone. So the mask had never fooled her at all. “Remove it,” Elzbieta said, almost gently. “Let’s not be vulgar.” Katra took a half-step forward; a rifle barrel lifted in precise synchrony. Aya lifted her hands, palms out, and with her thumbs hooked the silk edge of the half-mask. The fabric came away like shed skin. The chill air bit the fine sheen of sweat on her upper lip. Elzbieta’s gaze lingered on the blood-ink tattoo at Aya’s temple—a small circle bisected by three lines, sigil of the immateria. “Your mother’s artistry lives on, I see. How quaint. Bind them.” The guards moved with the bored efficiency of men who had done this a hundred times before. Hemp rope bit into Aya’s wrists, cinched behind her back. Katra tried a snarl, got the butt of a carbine in the ribs for her trouble; Simeon submitted with the quiet of someone already calculating angles, fuse lengths. Elzbieta resumed her post beside the relic. “The City Watch sang a pretty song of my capture. I let them. One must occasionally prune the vine—see which shoots dare reach for sun.” She regarded Aya as a lepidopterist might regard a pinned moth. “And here we find the blackest bloom. Tell me, girl, did you truly believe the guild could be led by a dilettante who plays with ghosts?” Aya’s tongue felt thick. “I believe,” she began, and was surprised at how steady her voice emerged, “that the guild has outgrown you. While you played prisoner, the docks whispered your weakness. I merely answered the vacancy.” Katra spat blood onto the flags. “Aya, don’t—” “Let her speak,” Elzbieta murmured. “I’m curious how the young reckon value these days.” Aya straightened, feeling the rope gnaw bone. “A Ravencrest hostage is worth more than a crate of opium or a hull of rifles. My father sits on the Admiralty Board. He will pay to have me unharmed—he must, lest the scandal poison our name.” She forced a laugh that tasted of rust. “And you know how the titled dread scandal, Elzbieta. It rots their teeth in their sleep.” Elzbieta tapped the flat of her cutlass against her boot. “You bargain for your life already? How swiftly nobility sheds its plumage. But you misreckon. I need no ransom; I require example.” Behind them, Simeon cleared his throat. “Then take the example that profits you least if you break it. Kill us, you get corpses. Keep us breathing, you get leverage—and, if she wills it, a Ravencrest heir who can open doors your current key-ring cannot.” Aya shot him a look—part gratitude, part horror at the price implied. Elzbieta considered. Gas-light hissed, painting her face amber, then blue, then amber again. “Leverage,” she repeated. “An interesting word from a guttersnipe engineer. Yet leverage bends both ways. What assurance have I that your little sorceress will not slit reality the moment my back is turned? Her mother danced upon air until the rope taught her better manners.” The memory rose unbidden behind Aya’s eyes: the square at dawn, the scent of tarred hemp, her mother’s boots kicking empty sky. A cold knot lodged beneath her sternum. She lifted her chin. “My mother reached too far, too fast, without allies. I am… more prudent.” Elzbieta’s eyebrow arched. “Prudent. Yes, I see prudence writ large in midnight burglaries and masked sedition.” She stepped closer; the cutlass glimmered like a slice of starlight. “Still, the blood of the Ravencrests is a rare vintage. Perhaps decanted slowly it might yield bouquet.” Aya felt the weight of Katra’s stare—*say whatever keeps us alive.* Simeon’s eyes flicked to the relic, calculating. She drew breath, tasting rust and candle smoke. “Keep me, then,” she said. “Let Katra and Simeon walk out. Their testimony to your mercy will quiet dissent faster than any gallows. The docks will see you magnanimous, not merely fearsome.” Katra started. “Like hell—” “Quiet.” Elzbieta raised a finger. Silence fell so complete Aya heard the distant drip of condensation onto iron. Then the guild leader laughed—a low, rich sound that scraped every shadow. “You offer terms as though seated in your father’s drawing room. Admirable, if absurd.” She turned, coat-tails flaring, and placed the flat of her blade against the bronze disk. “The relic has slept beneath my floorboards for twenty years. Every smuggler, every crown spy, every gutter mage has coveted it. Tonight it almost walked away wearing your perfume.” She spun back. “No. You will remain, all three. The tale of your capture will spread, and the tale of your eventual release—should I judge it politic—will serve better than any corpse. But first, girl, you will show me what your mother died for. You will open the gate you carry in that pretty vial, and we shall see whether the immateria recognises its own.” The gas-lamps flickered once, twice, then steadied, as though the air itself held breath. Aya felt the blood in the vial stir—warm, eager, treacherous. *Leverage bends both ways,* she thought, and met Elzbieta’s gaze without flinching. “Very well,” she said, voice soft as falling ash. “But know this, Guildmaster—what answers my call may not answer yours.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a tense, atmospheric scene in a whalepunk fantasy setting. The writer has crafted a vivid underworld environment with gas-pipes, whale-oil lanterns, and Victorian-gothic aesthetics that effectively establish the requested genre fusion. The prose demonstrates considerable skill in sensory detail and atmosphere. Descriptions like "grave-cold, cellar-cold, the exhalation of something that had waited far too long" and "shadows lengthened, shrank, lengthened again, as if the darkness itself were breathing" create a palpable sense of dread. The writer effectively uses architectural and environmental details to build the world: vaulted ceilings, basalt flags, carved stone walruses with ruby eyes. However, there are moments where the prose veers into purple territory. Phrases like "the exhalation of something that had waited far too long" and "her smile was a scalpel" feel somewhat overwrought. The metaphors occasionally strain credibility, as with "Katra followed, coat-tails sweeping like raven wings." The dialogue generally works well, capturing the Victorian-gothic tone requested. Elzbieta's formal, menacing speech ("Let's not be vulgar," "One must occasionally prune the vine") contrasts effectively with Katra's blunter style. The characters have distinct voices that reflect their positions and personalities. The piece follows the requested story beats faithfully: Aya is captured and unmasked, the trio are bound, and Aya attempts to negotiate based on her value as a hostage. The writer has incorporated the requested elements of magick being feared and barely understood, with references to Aya's mother being hanged for practicing immateria magick. Character motivations are mostly clear, though Simeon remains somewhat underdeveloped compared to Aya and Elzbieta. The internal conflict Aya experiences—between her aristocratic background and her criminal ambitions—is well-portrayed, especially in her calculated negotiation attempts. The ending effectively sets up tension for what might follow, with Elzbieta demanding Aya demonstrate her magical abilities. This creates a compelling cliffhanger that maintains the gothic horror elements while suggesting potential supernatural developments. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging, atmospheric scene with well-drawn characters. Its main weaknesses lie in occasional purple prose and some metaphors that feel forced rather than organic. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 86.3
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A lazy ceiling fan barely stirs the smoky air inside the bar. The blades spin like they’re too tired to care, just like everything else in the place—peeling wallpaper, cracked stools, and patrons too drunk to notice the mold on the ceiling. Neon signs flicker behind the counter, casting sickly pinks and greens across the faces of the damned and the desperate. The jukebox croons something mournful in a language no one here speaks. Spike Spiegel leans against the far wall, one boot propped on a chair, cigarette dangling from his lips like it’s been there forever. His suit jacket’s open, shirt untucked, and the yellowed bruise under his left eye is fresh enough to still throb when he blinks. His prosthetic eye catches the light wrong—too glossy, too still—and he turns his head just enough to track the woman who’s just walked in. Revy doesn’t knock. She kicks the door open like it owes her money and strolls in with the swagger of someone who’s shot men for looking at her wrong. Her twin cutlasses glint at her hips, and the dragon on her arm coils like it’s alive and pissed off. She’s in her usual uniform—tight black crop top, shorts that barely qualify as clothing, and boots that have stepped over more corpses than most people see in a lifetime. Her eyes scan the room once, twice, then land on Spike. He exhales smoke through his nose and gives her a lazy half-smile. “Well,” he says, “if it isn’t the infamous Two Hands. Heard you were dead.” Revy snorts and heads straight for the bar, hips swaying like a threat. “Heard the same about you, space cowboy. Guess we’re both ghosts.” They’re the only ones not pretending to be invisible. The bartender—a wiry man with a mustache like a broom—sets a bottle of cheap whiskey in front of her without being asked. She pours three fingers, downs it, then pours again. Spike watches her like a cat watches a snake. “You’re here for the Kuroda job,” she says, not a question. “Bingo,” Spike replies, flicking ash onto the floor. “Seems like we’ve got a scheduling conflict.” Revy turns, leaning her back against the bar, elbows resting on the wood like she owns the place. “Not my problem. I was here first.” “Funny,” Spike says, standing up. “Because I’ve got a tranq dart with his name on it, and a ship that’s already warmed up.” Revy’s laugh is sharp and ugly. “You think I came all this way to play nice? I don’t do tranqs. I do blood and fire.” Their eyes lock—his one human, one not; hers both dangerous and tired. There’s a beat of silence, thick with gunpowder and something else. Something that buzzes under the skin like static. She lifts her glass. “Drink?” He shrugs. “Why the hell not.” They move to a booth in the back, away from the windows, away from the exits. Revy sits with her back to the wall and her hands on her thighs, fingers twitching like they miss the weight of her guns. Spike lounges across from her, legs stretched out, cigarette burning slow between his fingers. They drink. Not like people who want to forget, but like people who want to remember something they’re not sure ever happened. Revy watches the way he moves—economical, like violence is just another dance step. Spike watches the way her lips wrap around the rim of the glass and the way her eyes never quite settle, always scanning, always judging. “You’re not what I expected,” she says eventually. “Disappointed?” “No,” she says, too quickly. “Just... thought you’d be taller.” He chuckles. “Yeah, well. Thought you’d be uglier.” She grins, all teeth and no warmth. “You’re lucky I’m feeling charitable.” “Or lazy,” he says. The tension stretches between them like wire. Revy leans forward, elbows on the table. “We could flip for it. Kuroda’s head. Winner takes all.” “You trust a coin?” “I trust my aim.” Spike stubs out his cigarette and lights another. “Nah. I don’t play fair. I play to win.” Revy’s hand twitches toward her holster. Spike’s doesn’t move, but his eyes flick down to her waist and back up again. “You wanna dance, cowboy?” she purrs. “Or just talk me to death?” He leans in, close enough that she can smell the smoke on his breath. “I don’t dance unless the music’s right.” She laughs again, low and dangerous, and then she’s standing, throwing bills on the table. “I’ve got a room next door. No windows. One door. You wanna settle this like civilized psychopaths, let’s go.” Spike raises an eyebrow. “Civilized?” “Relatively.” The motel is exactly what they both expected—flaking paint, buzzing lights, and a bed that’s seen things. The door clicks shut behind them like a gun being cocked. Revy locks it. Spike doesn’t stop her. They stand three feet apart, hands loose at their sides. “So,” she says. “You gonna try to shoot me in the back, or are we gonna do this the fun way?” Spike tilts his head. “Define fun.” Revy steps forward. He doesn’t move. She reaches up, fingers brushing the collar of his shirt, and for a second it’s not a threat—it’s something else. Something that burns hotter than gunmetal. Then her other hand draws. So does his. They’re nose to nose now, guns pressed under each other’s chins like lovers trading secrets. “You feel that?” Revy whispers. “That’s trust.” Spike smirks. “That’s stupidity.” They’re both breathing hard. The room is too small, the air too thick. Her knee brushes his. His thumb strokes the safety on his Jericho like it’s a heartbeat. Neither pulls the trigger. They stay like that—frozen, furious, and something else neither of them will name. Revy’s lips are inches from his. “You ever wonder what it’d feel like to stop running?” Spike’s voice is low, rough. “I stopped wondering a long time ago.” She doesn’t kiss him. He doesn’t kiss her. Instead, they lower their guns in perfect sync, like they rehearsed it. Revy steps back, holsters her piece. “Tomorrow. Noon. Kuroda’s mine.” Spike shrugs, already halfway out the door. “Whatever happens, happens.” The door clicks shut behind him. Revy lights a cigarette with shaking hands and doesn’t look at the bed.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story effectively captures the essence of both Spike Spiegel and Revy, creating a tense encounter between two skilled bounty hunters with similar trust issues but different approaches to their work. The piece excels in establishing atmosphere and character through economical yet evocative description. The opening paragraph immediately sets the tone with vivid imagery of a seedy bar, establishing the noir-like atmosphere that both source materials share. The descriptions are concise yet effective, painting a picture of decay and desperation that fits both characters' worlds. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Spike's laid-back fatalism and Revy's aggressive, confrontational nature are both well-represented. Their physical descriptions and mannerisms align perfectly with their canonical representations - Spike's casual posture and cigarette, Revy's swagger and revealing outfit. The writer has clearly understood both characters' essentials. The dialogue is exceptional, capturing both characters' distinctive voices. Spike's laconic, philosophical approach contrasts well with Revy's blunt, profane style. Their verbal sparring effectively builds tension while revealing character. Lines like "Whatever happens, happens" and the way they discuss their approach to the bounty feel authentic to both characters. The unresolved sexual tension is handled with subtlety and restraint. Rather than being explicit, it's conveyed through physical proximity, lingering glances, and the parallel between violence and attraction. The standoff in the motel room, with guns under each other's chins while standing close enough to kiss, perfectly encapsulates their relationship - mutual respect, attraction, and distrust all intertwined. The prose strikes a good balance between noir-style description and efficient storytelling. It avoids becoming purple or overwrought while still maintaining the stylistic elements appropriate to both source materials. The present tense narration creates immediacy that enhances the tension. The ending is appropriately unresolved, staying true to both characters' inability to form connections. Neither character compromises their essential nature, which would have felt false. Instead, they reach a temporary stalemate that feels earned and authentic. A few minor weaknesses: The story could have included more specific references to the bounty target to ground the conflict more concretely. Additionally, while the unresolved tension works thematically, some readers might find the lack of resolution slightly unsatisfying. Overall, this is an impressive character study that successfully merges two similar yet distinct fictional worlds, capturing the essence of both characters while creating a compelling standalone narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 88.0
Prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The mist, thick and luminous, rolled off the fields like it had somewhere urgent to be, only to stall at the foot of the mound, glowing under the moonlight like a held breath. We moved through it, Astrid first, sure-footed as a deer, me following, my borrowed wool coat scratching my neck. It was past midnight, the sky a bruised violet, the air sharp with the scent of pine needles and damp earth. My parents thought I was asleep in the small, spare room of the house they’d rented, a room that still smelled faintly of mothballs and the previous tenant’s pipe smoke. Instead, I was here, on the edge of the old cemetery, with Astrid, who moved through the world as if it belonged to her. “The veil is thinnest at the turning points,” Astrid had said earlier, her voice flat, like she was reciting a recipe. “Midnight. Solstice. New moon. And here, this place. The ancestors are listening.” She’d said it with the same casual certainty she used when explaining how to get a boy to notice you, or how to make your hair less frizzy. It was just another thing she knew, passed down from her grandmother, who’d lived in a croft at the edge of the forest and whose eyes, Astrid claimed, had seen things. I’d followed her because I was new, and Astrid was the only one who hadn’t looked at me like I was a foreign body. And because I was fifteen, and bored, and something in her conviction had scraped against my own skepticism, leaving a raw, curious patch. We weren’t going to *do* anything, not really. It was just a game, like the others. The midnight games. But this one, Útiseta, felt heavier. It was a sitting out, Astrid had explained, an old way to receive knowledge from beyond. A vigil. Not a séance, not a Ouija board, but a direct communion. Astrid stopped at the base of the mound. It was a low, rounded hill, covered in a scrim of moss and the dark silhouettes of dwarf pines. No gravestones, just an ancient, undisturbed quiet. She pulled a small, worn pouch from her pocket. Inside, she’d shown me earlier, were the things her grandmother had used: a pinch of dried herbs that smelled of something sharp and medicinal, a smooth, dark stone with a hole through its center, and a length of red wool thread. We were to sit, she’d said, facing the mound, backs to the village, backs to everything familiar. We would burn the herbs, whisper the names of those we sought knowledge about, and wait. We were not to speak, not until the knowledge came. And we were not to turn around. She knelt, her movements precise, and scraped a small hollow in the moss at the foot of the mound. Into it, she sprinkled the herbs. A faint, acrid scent rose. She struck a match, the small flare momentarily blinding, then the herbs caught, a thin plume of smoke spiraling upwards. She laid the holed stone carefully beside it, then took the red thread and tied it loosely around both our left wrists, binding us together. The wool was rough against my skin. It felt like a leash. “Now,” Astrid whispered, her voice barely a breath. “We sit. Back to the village. Back to the world. And we listen.” We settled onto the cold ground, the hard earth pressing into my tailbone. The mist swirled around us, luminous, almost alive. It was so quiet I could hear the blood rushing in my ears. Astrid’s breathing was slow, even. I stared at the mound, its dark bulk rising before us like a sleeping beast. The smoke from the herbs curled upwards, dissipating into the moonlit fog. I felt the chill seep into my bones, a dampness that went beyond the physical. The red thread pulled gently between us, a constant, slight pressure. At first, it was just the cold, and the quiet. The distant hoot of an owl. The rustle of something small in the undergrowth. My mind wandered, to my parents, asleep in their strange new house. To my old life, which already felt like a dream. Then, slowly, the silence began to shift. It thickened, became almost tangible. The mist seemed to press closer, muffling even the owl. I felt a prickle on the back of my neck, a sensation I tried to dismiss as the cold. But it grew, a distinct awareness of something *behind* me. I wanted to turn, desperately. The instruction not to turn around, which had seemed like a silly superstition, now felt like a command carved into stone. My heart began to beat faster, a frantic drum against my ribs. I strained my ears. Was it the wind? No, the air was still. Was it my imagination? I tried to tell myself it was. Just the darkness, the isolation, the power of suggestion. But the feeling persisted, a cold breath on the nape of my neck, a weight in the air that hadn’t been there before. The red thread tightened, almost imperceptibly, as if Astrid had shifted, or as if something had tugged at it. Then, I heard it. Not a sound, not exactly. More like a vibration, a low hum that seemed to emanate from the ground itself, from the very roots of the mound. It was subtle, almost below the threshold of hearing, but it resonated in my chest, a deep, ancient thrum. The mist, which had been swirling gently, began to eddy and twist, forming shapes that were gone as soon as I tried to focus on them. The scent of the burning herbs intensified, sharp and cloying, filling my lungs. I felt a strange pressure behind my eyes, a sudden, overwhelming urge to close them. And then, a whisper. Not a voice, not words, but a sensation, a knowing. A name. *Emil.* My classmate, the one who always seemed so quiet, so harmless. And with the name, a flash of something dark, a secret, a fear that wasn't mine, but that felt suddenly, intimately, like it was. A cold dread that settled deep in my stomach. My breath hitched. I wanted to scream, to tear my wrist free from the red thread, to run. But I was frozen, held by the pressure, by the hum, by the impossible knowledge that had just been *given*. Astrid remained utterly still beside me, her breathing unchanged. Was she feeling it too? Or was this all just me, the cold, the dark, the power of suggestion twisting my mind? The hum intensified, the mist swirling faster, and the cold on my neck sharpened into a distinct touch. Not wind. Not imagination. A pressure, like a hand, hovering, then a sudden, sharp pull on the red thread between us. Not Astrid. It came from the direction of the mound, from the earth itself. The red thread snapped taut, burning my wrist. And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, it stopped. The hum vanished. The mist stilled. The cold touch receded. The only sound was the frantic pounding of my own heart. Astrid stirred beside me. “It’s enough,” she whispered, her voice flat, devoid of any emotion. She reached down, untied the thread. My wrist felt raw where it had been. She scooped up the holed stone and the remnants of the herbs with a practiced hand. “We should go.” I scrambled to my feet, my legs stiff, my body trembling. The mist still clung to the edges of the mound, glowing under the moonlight, but it no longer looked luminous. It looked like a shroud. I didn’t look back at the mound as we walked away, Astrid leading me through the silent fields. I didn’t speak. My wrist throbbed. And the name, Emil, and the terrible thing I now knew about him, burned like a brand behind my eyes.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the folk horror atmosphere requested in the prompt, creating a tense, atmospheric narrative centered on the Útiseta ritual. The author has skillfully maintained the first-person past tense perspective of Linnea as requested, with strong attention to sensory details that immerse the reader in the eerie midnight setting. The writing excels at building tension gradually. Beginning with the girls' approach to the burial mound through the mist, the author establishes an unsettling tone that intensifies throughout the piece. The ambiguity between psychological suggestion and supernatural occurrence is well-maintained, particularly in how the narrator questions her own perceptions while experiencing increasingly disturbing phenomena. Character dynamics are convincingly portrayed. Astrid comes across as knowledgeable yet detached, treating ancient rituals with a casual familiarity that makes her character both intriguing and slightly unnerving. Linnea's motivations for participating—loneliness, curiosity, and teenage rebellion—feel authentic and provide a solid foundation for her willingness to engage in something that clearly frightens her. The prose is generally strong, with evocative descriptions that create a vivid sense of place. Particularly effective are the descriptions of the mist that "rolled off the fields like it had somewhere urgent to be" and later looks "like a shroud." The sensory details—the scratchy wool coat, the scent of pine needles and damp earth, the cold seeping into bones—ground the supernatural elements in physical reality. The ritual itself is presented with convincing specificity: the herbs, the holed stone, the red thread binding the girls together. These concrete elements lend credibility to the folk practice while serving as effective symbols throughout the narrative. Where the piece could be stronger is in its pacing toward the end. The climactic moment when Linnea receives knowledge about Emil feels slightly rushed, and the information received remains vague. While this maintains ambiguity, it somewhat diminishes the impact of what should be the most powerful moment in the narrative. Additionally, while the prose is generally strong, there are occasional instances where it becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors that call attention to themselves rather than enhancing the narrative flow. Overall, this is a compelling piece of folk horror that successfully balances psychological tension with supernatural suggestion. It effectively portrays the dangerous line between teenage experimentation and ancient practices, creating an unsettling narrative that lingers after reading. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
