+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The fluorescent bulb hanging from frayed copper wire flickers like it’s breathing its last. Below it, on a workbench that used to be a school desk, sits the heart of the settlement’s hope: a polymerase chain reaction rig built from the bones of dead corporations. At first glance the machine looks suicidal. Its heat block is a gutted espresso machine, the element rewound with nichrome scavenged from toaster coils. The lid is a cracked car-window motor that lifts exactly three millimetres—enough for a pipette tip, not enough for optimism. A pair of 1990s hard-drive magnets serve as the heated lid latch, and the whole mess is powered by a scavenged e-bike battery that smells faintly of burning plastic when it fast-charges from the wind turbine on the roof. I am the only one who doesn’t flinch at the smell. My name is Kae. Six years ago I was a junior CRISPR tech for GenLife Agritech, the same company that patented DNA planned-obsolescence, the same company whose logo still adorns the steel canisters I now use for reagents. The canisters once held proprietary “Recombinase Plus” cocktails, thirty grand a litre. Now they’re my distilled-water flasks; the stickers have long since peeled, leaving only the ghost of a barcode. Water is the easy part. Everything else degrades. The oligo primers I’m loading into the PCR tubes came from a shipment the raiders found in a refrigerated train car that derailed outside Toledo. The car had spent three summers exposed. The primers have terminal transferase tails that are literally fraying—like microscopic rope ends. I have to use them within eight hours or they’ll depurinate to uselessness. GenLife’s obsolescence schedule was forty-eight weeks; outside the cold chain it’s forty-eight hours. I slide the tubes home, close the suicidal lid, and thumb the toggle switch I soldered from a dead drone remote. The battery indicator blinks amber—enough for thirty cycles, no more. While the rig ramps to 95 °C I walk the five metres to the grow shelves: trays of sickly soybeans in rockwool, their leaves mottled with the tell-tale necrotic rings of GenLife’s Terminus trait. One generation and done; the second generation seeds commit apoptosis at the four-leaf stage. We’ve been living on the last viable harvest for two years. The settlement’s granary is down to three sacks. The contract I accepted last night sits folded in my breast pocket like a fever. Written on blue polymer film, the kind they used for stock options back when stocks meant something. It promises three drums of purified diesel and a roll of actual copper tubing in exchange for one thing: splice a trait into fast-germinating millet that will let it fix nitrogen without symbiotic bacteria. The signature is just a thumbprint—black market doesn’t use names—but I recognise the whorls. Rell, the diesel baron from the river encampment, who keeps two armed kids on hair-trigger leashes. The same Rell whose mother died because GenLife’s insulin analogue expired in her bloodstream six months too early. I should hate them all, but hunger is a persuasive translator. The PCR rig beeps, a thin electronic cough. First denaturation complete. I move to the hood: an old biosafety cabinet whose HEPA filter has been replaced with furnace filter felt soaked in iodine. It smells like a hospital morgue. Under the hood waits the real prize—an ice bucket cobbled from a Styrofoam shipping crate stamped “Live organs, handle with prayer.” Inside, nested in wet paper, are the gene fragments Rell delivered this morning: six micrograms of Rhizobium nif cluster excised from a pre-Collapse seed vault genome, the DNA cut with ancient EcoRI and PstI sites. The fragments are already showing single-strand nicks; I can see them as faint smears on the improvised gel box I built from a CD case and nine-volt battery clips. I pipette 1 µL of the fragments into the waiting Gibson master mix—homebrew, of course. Phusion polymerase long dead; instead I’m using a fungal Bst I purified from compost. It’s error-prone as gossip but heat-stable and free. Add buffer made from melted Tums tablets and a speck of lithium grease to reduce evaporation. The Gibson reaction will chew the nicks, chew the homology arms, and—if the gods of biochemistry are kind—sew the nitrogen-fix cluster into the millet chloroplast vector I designed last week. While the assembly incubates at 50 °C (inside a sous-vide cooker I pulled from a flooded Cheesecake Factory), I roll up my sleeve. The veins on my left forearm are livid green. Two months ago I injected myself with an uncharacterised phage lysin that promised to chew the prion-like protein plaques GenLife’s edible vaccines left in everyone over thirty. I didn’t expect to survive; I just couldn’t watch another elder choke on their own memories. The injection site ulcerated, then granulated, then sealed. The plaques are still there—MRI confirmed with a scavenged veterinary imager—but something else happened: my lactate threshold doubled. I can run up the turbine tower three flights without breathing hard. My night vision is predatory. Side effect, mutation, or gift, I don’t know. I do know the settlement now calls me “Glow,” half affection, half superstition. I draw 5 mL of my own blood into a heparinized syringe and spin it in a salad-spinner centrifuge to harvest serum. I need human growth factors for the millet protoplasts—corporate media recipes assume lab-grade supplements, but my serum works better, maybe because the prion fragments act like adjuvants. I pour off the straw-colored supernatant. My reflection in the plexi looks like someone who’s been dipped in moonlight: pale, luminous scars on the arms, pupils blown wide. Assembly time’s up. I pipette 2 µL into electrocompetent millet cells I made by soaking embryos in mannitol and plasmid detergent stolen from a hair-conditioner factory. Zap them at 1.8 kV using a disposable-camera flash circuit. The smell of ozone is an old friend. While the cells rest in recovery broth, I pull out the contract. Rell wants the seeds in fourteen days. Impossible, unless I push the plants with the same reckless vector I used on myself. I weigh diesel against ethics. Diesel wins. I design an additional insert: a CRISPR guide that knocks out the plant’s circadian inhibitor, plus a small peptide tag that should bind my modified serum factors. If it works, the millet will grow to harvest in forty-five days, nitrogen fixed, seeds viable—at least for one generation. If it fails, the settlement starves faster. Midnight. The turbine screams in the wind like a living thing. I load the transformed embryos onto petri dishes made from old smartphone glass and slide them into the incubator: a polystyrene cooler warmed by an array of tealights floating in water. The temperature drifts between 28 °C and 32 °C, a lullaby of uncertainty. I pull the steel canister labelled “Recombinase Plus” close, run my thumb over the faded barcode. Inside, now, is just buffer and hope. I whisper an apology to whatever genetic ghosts still listen. Then I roll up my sleeve again, draw another 10 mL of my glowing blood, and add it to the recovery broth. Symbiosis, self-experimentation, desperation—call it what you want. Tomorrow the seeds will drink me. In fourteen days Rell will come with drums and guns. I flip off the lab light. The PCR rig ticks as it cools, counting time the way only broken machines can. Somewhere in the dark, new genomes are waking up, stitched together with duct tape and hubris. They will either feed us or finish us. Either way, the cycle is running.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter presents a compelling vision of a post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering has collapsed society through planned obsolescence. The narrative follows Kae, a former GenLife Agritech employee turned biohacker, who works with salvaged equipment to create viable food crops for their settlement. The worldbuilding is exceptional, with detailed descriptions of jury-rigged lab equipment that feel authentic and inventive. The PCR rig made from an espresso machine, car-window motor, and hard-drive magnets creates a vivid image of technological desperation. The author skillfully weaves technical terminology throughout without overwhelming the reader, creating a believable scientific backdrop. The character of Kae is well-developed despite the brevity of the piece. Their background as a former corporate employee adds complexity to their current role, and their self-experimentation with untested genetic modifications demonstrates both desperation and commitment. The physical toll and unexpected upsides of these modifications are effectively portrayed through the "livid green" veins and enhanced physical abilities. The black market contract with Rell serves as an effective plot device, creating tension and moral conflict. Kae's decision to accept the contract despite ethical concerns illustrates the harsh realities of survival in this world. The line "I weigh diesel against ethics. Diesel wins" succinctly captures this moral compromise. The prose is elegant and evocative, with striking metaphors and sensory details that immerse the reader in this decaying world. Lines like "The fluorescent bulb hanging from frayed copper wire flickers like it's breathing its last" and "The PCR rig ticks as it cools, counting time the way only broken machines can" demonstrate sophisticated writing that enhances the atmosphere. However, there are a few minor issues. The piece occasionally veers into overly technical language that might alienate readers unfamiliar with genetic engineering concepts. While this fits the genre, some passages could be more accessible without sacrificing authenticity. The ending feels slightly rushed, with the fourteen-day timeline introduced late in the narrative. While the conclusion effectively captures the uncertainty and desperation of Kae's situation, it might have benefited from more development of the potential consequences of failure. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of biopunk fiction that successfully combines scientific plausibility with emotional resonance. The author has created a richly detailed world populated by complex characters facing morally ambiguous choices, all while maintaining a consistent tone and engaging narrative flow.
